B000B8QEZG|5.0|It's funny reading what 'naysayers' write on this,because it's written based on trivial purposes,..or for some malicious negative intent.  I have purchased 3 Madonna albums in my life. Ray of Light, American Life and this new one.  I have of course heard many of her other albums and her early dance singles are embedded in my brain of my childhood and adolescent experience.  But as an adult (that's over 30), I find this album to be her BEST EVER!  It is simply retro-simply obscure-simply unapologetic.   <br />the words are SUPPOSED to be simple..there is no need to search for deep lyrical content..it is SUPPOSED to be a fun, non threatening..sometimes silly, get up off your butt and dance album.  <br /> The songs are all mixed..giving it a non-stop party vibe.  Many styles of dance music are interpreted, 70's , 80's, 90's now and beyond.  It takes a good 3 or 4 listens for these songs to JUMP out at you and once again stay in your head forever. <br />  It crosses influences of Kraftwerk, DOnna Summer, Tom Tom Club, and even her own hits like a prayer and papa don't preach. <br /> <br />BUT NOTHING IS SAMPLED except the ABBA on HUNG UP (Hung Up is acyually my least favorite of the whole album)...the rest of the styles are cleverly crafted and produced in a swirl of circling sped rhythms, and many of the songs stand on their own. <br /> <br />DJ's will be going crazy on this album for the rest of the year...and it is perfect for a workout.  or cleaning around the house. <br /> <br />anyone who doesnt bop theior heads or tap their foot during this album seriously has a problem. <br /> <br />This is a great addition to my cd collection,..and it might even compell me to pick up some of her older material. <br /> <br />By the way,..I thought Ray of Light was phenomenal...I think Confessions on a dancefloor is even better. <br /> <br />I don't need to judge Madonna's choices, political opinions, what she does with her children, who she kisses, or what her age is. <br /> <br/>This has proven to me that age doesn;t matter. <br />When you are making good music and a fun, dance record. All that stuff doesn;t matter.  Madonna in my book, has been a true artist who has challenged the masses, questioned and explored, divided and united people...and that is what a true artist is.  Luckily for us,..she has put herself out there for over 20 years...and is still going strong.  She has never succumbed to falling off the planet,..or ever taking a break.  She keeps going...and I think that threatens people. <br /> <br />This album is pure fun!  and a great way to escape!

B000A2WF3S|5.0|Let it never be said that Gidon Kremer's interpretations are in any way similar to... well, anyone. This is truly a fresh, and let me stress alternative take on these works- I would not recommend these to anyone not first initiated to Bach solo violin. If I were to recommend a place to start with these pieces, it would be Arthur Grumiaux, Henryk Szeryng, Nathan Milstein, or Hilary Hahn, as they present more (for lack of a better term) \\"mainstream\\" versions without Kremer's tendency towards more esoteric (yet totally effective) interpretations.    However, to those of you out there who are already familiar with the works, I say have at it: Kremer's reading is heartfelt, idiomatic, and very staccato yet never mechanical. He is certainly a student of performance, individuality, and taste. It is also quite worth it to hear the cleanliness of these discs: the sound and recording quality, as in all ECM recordings, is absolutely stellar.
B000B8QEZG|5.0|The long wait is finally over and Madonna has done it once more. <br />Confessions on a Dancefloor is a non-stop mix of twelve tracks that review different styles of dance music, all of them reworked for a fresh sound. <br /> <br />Lyrically this is not Madonna's best work, but when you do dance music, the lyrics have to adapt to a certain beat or they don't work at all. <br /> <br />Hung Up is the first single and it's an upbeat, just dance and enjoy yourself kind of song. It samples ABBA's \\"Gimme Gimme Gimme (A Man After Midnight) in a very clever way. <br /> <br />Get Together is the first love song, very good for a slow dance, just follow Madonna and \\"Get Together\\" with a significant other. <br /> <br />Sorry (confirmed 2nd single) is a very catchy song, this one may not like you the first time but it definitely grows on oneself, you'll be repeating the chorus in no time. <br /> <br />Future Lovers which is reminiscent of Donna Summer's \\"I Feel Love\\" and an obvious homage. It has a very fresh sound, if you know  Donna's sound then this song will feel very familiar. <br /> <br />I Love New York, ok, dance music isn't compatible with good lyrics but this one just can't be justified. It's silly, and very  weak. \\"I don't like cities, but I Love New York\\"/\\"Other cities, make me feel like a dork\\"--What the???. <br /> <br />This five songs are a different chapter on the album, probably referencing Madonna's first kind of silly (but good) songs and then we slowly get stronger lyrics like her present career offers. <br /> <br />Let It Will Be starts with a violin which reminds of \\"Papa don't Preach\\" or \\"Die Another Day\\", it's very good in the lyrics but the sound doesn't really feel like something new. <br /> <br />Forbidden Love, my personal favorite track is the second love song and has Madonna telling a tale of two lovers \\"Once upon a time, there was a boy and there was a girl\\"/\\"Hearts that intertwined, they lived in a different kind of world\\". It's the slowest song on the album but it's simply addictive with it's chorus saying \\"Forbidden Love\\"/\\"Are we supposed to be together?\\". <br /> <br />Jump (the 3rd single) is one of the best songs on the album, very upbeat, but you have to listen this one for yourself, after hearing it, you'll find yourself jumping all over the place. <br /> <br />How High brings back the preachy Madonna, but what a good prayer she has made!!!. Whether you like the lyrics or not (it talks about fame) \\"How high are the stakes?\\"/\\"How much fortune can you make?\\"/\\"Should I carry on?\\"/\\"Will it matter when I'm gone?\\", I assure you that this one will make you dance all over the place too. It probably has the more electronic sound of all the album. <br /> <br />Isaac can only be enjoyed if you're open to accept the sounds from cultures of South-eastern Europe or Asia that may make-it or breake-it. Although not very danceable, it's good on it's own. It's very tied to Madonna's study of Kabbalah. <br /> <br />Push has an R&B sound and a very good one at that, if you like R&B you'll simply fall in love with this song. It has a very good mood. <br /> <br />Like It Or Not really doesn't fit the theme of this album, it's Madonna's critic to the media, it's strong lyrically but it sounds nothing like dance music. Good track nonetheless.

'Darkness' hit me in the gut the way no other album ever had or has ever had since. We decided to try to meet him after one show and went to the stage door and waited until around 5 in the morning. Other band members walked out, a few apparently very impressed with themselves (Max Weinberg you know who you are)then out he came in a Ford Bronco with a driver. When it was my turn to approach him I had nothing for him to sign except the sweaty folded stub for the show, but he took it and made a joke about it to put me at my ease. And he became a bit of a god for me, for awhile.<br /><br />So, before the 'Darkness' set in for Bruce, the depression years of 'The River' and the desolated 'Nebraska' the MEGA \\"BornInTheUSA' (which so got on my nerves with how misunderstood the title song was--does anyone else remember crowds at the shows pumping fists and waving flags like they were at a Nazi rally or something. I don't find it derivative of \\"We Belong Together\\" at all. It's a great track. The last song on the album is the remix to \\"We Belong Together\\". 0930289528|5.0|About two or three years ago, I read just about every single dystopian novel I could get my hands on; call it a bizarre phase brought on by adolescence, but for some reason, V for Vendetta escaped my attention until quite recently, perhaps because it was a graphic novel.  I stumbled across some sort of cheesy promotion for the movie quite by accident, took one look at the synopsis, and decided it was worth a sampling of the source material.  I read about fifteen pages before deciding that I had to have a copy of my own. <br /> <br />That was probably the best book buy I've made this year.  V for Vendetta has a sort of edgy, gritty, hyper-reality that few novels in any genre possess.  The juxtaposition of the ordinary with the ugly and the unnerving is brilliant and wonderfully jarring.  What perhaps surprised me the most was the subtlety and depth in V for Vendetta.  Most books about dystopian futures can be distilled into \\"Government system/philosophy/belief X is bad and will crush humanity.\\"  V for Vendetta presents two equally misunderstood and maligned ideologies, anarchy and fascism; there is no one fighting for \\"justice\\" or \\"truth\\" or all of those trite terms we've been bombarded with since grade school.  We are left with questions about V, Susan, and whether violence is truly justified.  V in particular forces us to ponder questions we probably never dreamed of: very few people question justice as a noble ideal, yet V leaves an explosive Valentine and a disturbing speech at the feet of Madam Justice.   <br /> <br />I strongly recommend V for Vendetta, but with this caveat: it is unwise for those who cannot or will not attempt to understand the implications of actions in the book to read it.  It's not by any means necessary to understand the plot; for the most part, the surface story is fairly straightforward, even if the white, mid-level bureaucratic men are a little hard to keep track of.  But it's not the story of V for Vendetta that counts.  It's the message, the idea, that gives V his true power.  Neither is it necessary to recognize all the allusions to previous literature and philosophy, but again, the more you know, the more V for Vendetta will offer. <br />

B000B8QEZG|5.0|With the release of this album, madonna has finally reached a place of creativity unseen in any of her previous works. Whilst Ray Of Light was a masterful album, and signalled the modern era madonna, everything about this album just feels right. The production is flawless, the lyrics range between the introspective to the down-right campy, and the beats are out of this world. this album comes 'premixed', meaning you can simnply pop it in at any party, and forget about skipping any tracks. <br /> <br />Hung Up 10/10:  <br />What can I say, this is one brilliant song, and a wonderful way to kick off the album. The ABBA sample is a bonus to the infectious lyrics and pounding beat. <br /> <br />Get Together 10/10: <br />Absolute perfection. You will honestly believe you have been transported into an Eighties Discoteque, with platforms and all. The chorus to this song is pure pop perfection, and madonna's Vocals are a throwback to here early days. <br /> <br />Sorry 10/10: <br />Rounding out the strongest opening trilogy of any madonna album ever-made, is Sorry, a song so infectious and pefect, you won't believe your ears. This song hails the return of the sexy madonna, who isn't gonna take any crap from an ex-lover. The lyrics are second to the pulsating beat, immaculately produced by Stuart Price. <br /> <br />Future Lovers 9/10: <br />Future Disco would be the best way to describe the sound of this track. A sexy Spoken introduction, ala erotica, brings the song into a viciously grinding beat, which will have you in the 'zone' in no time. <br /> <br />I Love New York 10/10: <br />Attention critics, stop criticising the lyrics to this song. They are intetionally simple and camp, and if you can't pick that up, then you shouldn't be listening to a Madonna album in the fist place. Driving melody and beat, will have you hooked instantly. <br /> <br />Let It Will Be 9/10:  <br />Spiritual and Wiser Madonna kicks in at this point, but don't worry, the beat and production morethan makes up for it. Lyrically, I think this is one of the stronger tracks on the record, and fans will appreciate it. <br /> <br />Forbidden Love 10/10: <br />This song is suprisingly haunting, yet sexy, and is definately one of the album's highlights. The trance-like beat, coupled with sexy and sensual lyrics, make this a must listen. Far superior to the 1994 Forbidden Love. <br /> <br />Jump 10/10: <br />High energy retro jam, that will have you on your feet and jumping in no time. This is slated for release as a single, and will definately do well. <br /> <br />How High 11/10:  <br />My favourite song on the album. The lyrics are heart-felt, as madonna confesses her egotistic past desires. The chrous is to die for, with a bass line that will have your house shaking. Pure perfection , and possible the best madonna song of all time. The entire album is worth purchasing just for this track. <br /> <br />Isaac 8/10: <br />This is Madonna's tribute to kabballah, and like it or not, the infectious melody will have you hooked. Pure genius <br /> <br />Push 9/10: <br />This is the sexiest Madonna song in a while. Lyrically, she is thanking a certain someone for 'pushing' her to be a better person. An infectious, but simple, beat drives the song. <br /> <br />Like It Or Not 10\10: <br />This is a great way to end an amazing album, and has a breathier air to it, as if the party is ending, and you are the last one left. Excellent track! <br /> <br />So basically, if you only purchase one album this year, let it be this one.

The solos sound sort of like an Eddie Van Halen solo, except more random, noisier and suckier; I can't stand them, and that was the tiebreaker between 3 and 4 stars, causing me to give this album three stars.  Still, I do recommend the album.   <br /> <br />The fact that I think this album is more than \\"just okay\\" speaks well for Audioslave, since it's hard for me to listen to this sort of music anymore - at least to get to give a new hard rock album half a chance.  I still think that \\"Be Yourself\\" and \\"Doesn't Remind Me\\" are the best songs musically, and I have not heard them too much on the radio because I rarely listen to the sorts of radio stations that play those songs.  I have not listened closely to the songs' lyrics yet though.  Other people here seem to think that the lyrics are actually quite good, so keep that in mind when listening to the album. <br /> <br />I've never listened to the Audioslave's first album (and probably never heard any songs from it) and I don't usually listen to this type of music.  Well, I did back in the 90s in the heyday of Brendan O'Brien-produced hard rock acts like Stone Temple Pilots, Pearl Jam and of course Soundgarden, but nowadays I find myself listening to singer-songwriters and rock/pop groups more often.  I have Toad the Wet Sprocket, Weezer, Killers, Nelly Furtado, Kathleen Edwards, Jack Johnson, Bonnie Raitt, Modest Mouse, and Green Day CDs at work now.  I guess I've mellowed out, even though I'm only 27. <br />
0553801503|5.0|Five long, long years ago, a nineteen year old (going on twenty) college student finished \\"A Storm of Swords\\", with the tremendous revelation of the transformation of Catelyn Stark, the demise of Tywin Lannister, the fall of Lysa Arryn, with a changed, war ravaged Westeros- and with the prospect of a two years wait for \\"A Dance with Dragons\\", where all these plotlines, and more, would be continued.    Time passed.  The Israeli-Palestinian Peace Process has failed and rose and collapsed again.  The Twin Towers have fallen, as has the regime of Sadam Hussein.  George W. Bush is still the American President, properly elected this time.  The college student is now in another country, with a new job and new complications.  I've known love bitter and true, met new people and seen new places, had new experiences.  I've fronted a rock band and stopped, almost entirely, reading Fantasy fiction.  I've AGED.    As for George R. R. Martin, too, things have changed.  The Dragons will still dance, but not in this book.  Now the Crows are feasting, and the planned gap between the events of books 3 and 4 in A Song of Ice and Fire is gone- along with Martin's assurances that there will be six books and six only.    So, across this gap - a new world, a different reader, an altogether different book then the one expected - what does the 25 year old me say about the continuation of the saga I fell in love with in my teens?  Does it still hold out?  What it the verdict?    Well, it's utterly, absolutely, no holds barrel brilliant.    Oh, there are faults.  There always has been.  This series is imperfect, and from a technical point of view, this volume is the weakest in the series, so far.  Critics are right to complain about the pace, about the absence of our favorite characters, of Brienne running into all of the characters from \\"A Storm of Swords\\".  The structure is weaker as well - do we really need three new point of view characters each for the events of Dorn and the Iron Islands?Davos had been all the eyes we ever needed for Stannis's Court - why do we need so many onlookers on the Dornish Marshes?    But this is not the point and never has been.  Martin's books are about his world, his dream, his characters and history and drama.  Its about the creeping magic and the gathering storm, it's about the bloody aftermath as well as the glorious battles, and the way in which the great revolutions leave a terrible after taste.  The War of the Five Kings is over.  This is the aftermath - it's messy, it's terrible - and, like the rest of A Song of Ice and Fire, it's true to real life (with Dragons).    Unlike the previous books, a Feast for Crows is more a character study then an action thriller.  Meet Tywin Lannister's sister, Genna, and her observation that Tyrion, and Jaime, is Tywin's son.  See Jaime's Lannister's hurt from the betrayal of his sister.  Meet Sansa Stark's struggles to survive, and Samwell's Tarly struggles for honor.  Encounter the Master Aemon Targaryen, in exile from his last home on the wall.  This is their story.  This is the Song of Ice and Fire.     So the twenty-five years old me closed the last pages of \\"A Feast for Crows\\" with all the reverence that my nineteen years old self opened \\"A Game of Thrones\\".  I hope that I won't have to wait another five years to read the first lines of \\"A Dance with Dragons\\", but as long as the Song is true, the signs that time leave on both the Singer and the Audience will not prevent me from asking for an encore.

0553801503|3.0|A Feast for Crows (AFfC) picks up right where the action left off in A Storm of Swords. Perhaps I should say storyline rather than action - AFfC is severely lacking in action and intrigue. For those of you that enjoy world-building and meeting new characters in a now familiar fantasy world, you will be well served. Also, if you enjoy the minutiae of details about noble houses, and the everyday gore of a war-torn medieval land you have plenty to feast upon.  Otherwise.... <br /> <br />Characters <br />If you are hoping to read more about the characters that you got hooked on at the beginning of the series, be careful. Of the 8 original Game of Thrones POV characters (Arya, Bran, Catelyn, Danaerys, Eddard, Jon, Sansa and Tyrion), 2 are given voice in this volume for a grand total of 6 chapters. For some of us, that hurts. The few Samwell and Arya chapters will not disappoint, and Jaime has his moments.  <br /> <br />Pacing and Plot <br />Although similar in size to A Game of Thrones (AGoT), this volume is much slower in pace, which can be highlighted by the big difference in the number of chapters - 46 for AFfC vs. a whopping 73 for AGoT. Less chapters means a slower gait, and the sometimes breathless pace of the first three volumes is all but gone, as the events that are covered here focus on what happens as the war (at least temporarily) dies down. <br /> <br />Development <br />There are 9 new POV characters in this volume, many of whom get little screen time and less action. This makes for much less of a payoff in terms of character development, as new characters step in and out of the story before the reader can form a connection with their perspective. As for the 3 characters which carry the bulk of the book, none of them has the charisma of a Jon or Tyrion and none of them undergo any significant character shifts, either. The Martin hallmark of a bad guy turning good or a good guy turning bad is sorely missed. <br /> <br />Outlook <br />Martin is clearly tryingto expand the scope of his series, and a book about recovering from war is both realistic and clearly meant to establish a new order for the conflicts that will undoubtedly arise in future volumes. Despite my criticisms, I doubt that this is a novel which most Martin fans will want to skip. Read it. Absorb. And let's hope that Martin realizes that an endless cast of POVs from around the world does not have the same dramatic effect as following the trials and tribulations of just a few characters.

0375701427|5.0|Philip Roth, certainly among the half-dozen very best novelists writing in America during the second half of the Twentieth Century, will be among the very few still read a hundred years from now. And it wouldn't surprise me if AMERICAN PASTORAL is at the top of his reading list. It's his masterpiece.<br /><br />Swede Levor, legendary Newark High School athlete, inheritor of his father's glove factory, husband of former Miss New Jersey, seems to have it all. But then his daughter commits an act of political terrorism, a bombing, that leaves people dead. Swede's world is shattered, and he tries to figure out where and why the train has derailed.<br /><br />It's in this inner searching that Roth proves his mastery as a writer. Told in the words of a first-person omnipotent narrator, Swede's life story unfolds. The tone of the book is perfect: steady, informative, never hysterical - though the bitterness and incomprehension of Swede's daughter's (her name is, ironically, Merry) act is fully brought out. Roth's command of language and his deep understanding of his characters are magnificently displayed. We are drawn into the story effortlessly and the challenge to understand Swede's life and his daughter's motivation is made so compelling that it becomes difficult to put the book down. Without a doubt, this is Roth's best novel (PORTNOY'S COMPLAINT  and THE PROFESSOR OF DESIRE are his next best books, but even they lack the power and authority shown here). A marvelous achievement.

But I'm never going away.' That should be good enough for everyone. <br /> <br />Lastly, buy this album. You will be pleasantly surprised.
140004281X|5.0|Alice Munro's stories are less about plot and more about mood --like no other author, she is able to evoke feelings with a single sentence -- to convey a character's despair, loneliness, sense of isolation and brief happiness with only a word or two. I can never quite grasp how she does it.<br /><br />These stories, which take place throughout Canada, are about people escaping, or trying to escape, their narrow lives. Three stories are entertwined with the same characters, and we get almost a novella that is impossible to put down. In each case, Munro manages to pull us in to the minds of her characters, even when, as is often the case, we have nothing whatsoever in common with them--and even though they are not always likeable.<br /><br />I won't detail the stories here because they need discovery. Simply open the book and fall into the pages and be thrilled by Munro's always brilliant writing.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|Madonna and her production team have put out what is clearly the album of her career. Outdoing \\"Music\\", \\"Like a Prayer\\" or any of her stronger work from the 1990s and 1980s, \\"Confessions..\\" is a brilliant nonstop homage to the history of dance music, with electro-synth heavy tracks reminsicent of Donna Summer, Kraftwerk, Irene Cara, New Order and early Madonna herself. With the absence of any filler whatsoever, \\"Confesions..\\" is a finely crafted dance-pop gem, and a fantastic transition from the more serious mood of \\"American Life.\\" With no weak tracks to speak of, \\"Hung Up\\" is definitely not an album stand out. That honor belongs to \\"Sorry\\", \\"Jump\\" and \\"Isaac.\\" With haunting background chanting, \\"Isaac\\" has a sound unlike any other track heard in recent years. \\"Forbidden Love\\" is another instant classic, with a crisp melody and ear shattering beat. But the song that makes this album worth buying on its very own, is \\"Let it Will Be\\". Thumping, pulsating, sorrowful and addictive all at the same time, this is pure unadultered Madonna. Just when you think this woman cannot get any better, she puts out an album with songs more fierce than anything out there today.

B00008BXJF|5.0|Dark glamor and a beauty as clear and as fragile as a rose appear in the music of King Crimson's \\"The Power To Believe\\".  I feel as I listen to this work as if King Crimson has long since survived the fall of a thousand ages  and moved into a future age so remote it bares little resemblance to our own.  There is a sense of doom and psychological complexity so apparent in much of King Crimson's greatest music since long, long ago they led us into the Court of the Crimson King.  At moments I feel as if I woke in a city tens of thousands of years hence and I listen to the sounds of the city from a hotel room on a street whose name I cannot remember.  Past all bearings and all reckonings there is still a power to believe.    Why is it that King Crimson can combine age with such great vitality?  So many other rock acts long since have outlived their usefulness.  They become mere ghosts of what they once were while their legends beckon with a power that no longer exists to make music as equally great in the present.  Not so with the Crimson King.  They are the not-quite-icey survivors of rock music taking it into dimensions of feeling that shock and unsettle, creating a beauty that provokes unease.    It's a great pity that the corporate rock world celebrates guitarists like Hendrix or the Edge of U2 ( great guitarists, to be sure) in a delirium of rock orthodoxy while Robert Fripp is largely ignored.  Fripp cannot be controlled or classified.  He began doing things with the guitar at an early age that can only be called uncanny.  And now, thousands of years into a remote future he still does things with a guitar that can only be called uncanny.  There is a sound coming out of his guitar that fills the whole album with a sense that we might learn to live in a time of real legends walking this earth once again.

B0002G2B2M|3.0|What a brainteaser! This movie was crafted very carefully, so don't be suprised if you spend the rest of the evening trying to figure it out! And when you do, it will certainly impact you.<br /><br />There are a number of things I really don't like about this movie, but I think it does bring out some very pertinent issues and raises a number of important questions. Some of them include: To what extent can the mind be tampered with? What role does manipulation play in relationships? How does easy access to technology change human relationships? Is there a difference between the \\"mind\\" and the physical \\"brain\\"? Is there any sort of consciousness that trancends the physical aspects of the brain? Are we comfortable enough with mind-altering technology to entrust the manipulation of our brain to a particular company or organization? Is there a distinction between reality and fantasy, existence and non-existence, and if so--how can we know it?<br /><br />In some ways this film is horror. Why? Because our society, technologically and ethically speaking is not on a much different level. We (society in general) lack a sufficient moral and ethical basis that would give us form (limitations) that would prevent the If-We-Can-Do-It-We-Will-Do attitude that is often prevelant in technological development. Freedom without form is an invitation to disaster. The question of whether X or Y or Z is harmful or immoral becomes a moot point when society has determined that something is in its reach and finds no sufficient basis in its worldview for moral absolutes. This film is a stark portrayal of this.<br /><br />One thing of note about this movie is that this is an atypical role for Jim Carey. He seems to fit into the role, though!

0975991477|5.0|Bruce Lipton's extraordinary book THE BIOLOGY OF BELIEF is destined to revolutionize the way we think about the effects our  thoughts have on our bodies at the cellular level. Lipton writes with enthusiasm, warmth and passion about the role of the environment in regulating gene activity, with the authority of having had decades of published scientific papers which pre-date the official start of the brand new scientific field of epigenetics.<br /><br />Not only do our thoughts directly influence our health and well-being, but we are probably unable to heal or succeed without them. Lipton states, \\"The placebo effect should be the subject of major, funded research efforts. If medical researchers could figure out how to leverage the placebo effect, they would hand doctors an efficient, energy-based, side effect-free tool to treat disease.\\"<br /><br />THE BIOLOGY OF BELIEF really shines when describing the relevance of cutting-edge scientific findings to our daily lives. Lipton writes with such sparkling, down-to-Earth words that it's a real pleasure to take them fully and deeply to heart. And when we do, we can feel glad that the world will no longer be the same.
B00005JODA|4.0|\\"The constant gardener\\" is an extremely good movie that could have been exceptional but somehow doesn't reach that point. In my opinion, the director, Fernando Meirelles, should be recognized for doing an excellent job in what ended up being an outstanding (and thouroughly non-linear) film. Even though I didn't like this movie as much as I loved Meirelles' previous film, \\"City of God\\", it easy to see that he retains his gift for surprising the spectator, and treating him with scenes of astonishing beauty.<br /><br />The plot is, in general, the same of the book. Justin Quayle (Ralph Fiennes), the main character, is an extremely polite English diplomat working in the British Embassy in Kenya. He who has only two passions in his life: gardening  and his wife Tessa (Rachel Weisz). Tessa isn't overly conventional, and can be downright rude when she is defending one of her many causes, while Justin is taking care of his garden. Despite their differences, they complement each other. Justin, oblivious to the reality that surrounds him in Kenya, grounds himself in Tessa, and can't imagine his life without her.<br /><br />Unfortunately, when some hired guns kill Tessa, Justin will have to learn if he will be able to live in a world without Tessa. His more immediate concern, however, is why was she killed. Justin's life is thrown into turmoil, and danger abounds, as he learns that Tessa was investigating the shady dealings of an important pharmaceutical company working in Kenya. But what did she discovered? Justin won't stop until he learns just that, finishing what his wife started.<br /><br />On the whole, I think I can recommend this movie as high-quality entertainment, fast-paced enough to engage even those who don't like \\"slow\\" films. B000B8QEZG|4.0|This is definately one of Madonna's most original studio albums. She's dabbled a little in each genre, including R&B, pure pop, techno, trance, and now on \\"Confessions\\" she takes on disco. Yeah, it seems odd at first, but then you're easily able to slip into this \\"future disco\\" genre that she's hyped for the past few months while working on this album.<br /><br />She said this is all dance, no ballads. Perhaps that's true, but I still felt like she slipped in a very trendy, likeable ballad or two. One of the most appealing and interesting things about this album is that all the tracks are mixed together. They're still seperated by track numbers but the music itself blends together so that there's never a pause or still moment while you're listening to the CD. Each track is also mixed to sound like it's been remixed. Instead of having one or two dull tracks that will turn into a hot remix later on, we have a CD full of tracks that have already been given a club-ready mixing.<br /><br />For those disapointed by \\"American Life,\\" I think you'll find that this is more appealing. It's fast paced, no techno-folk tracks. Mirwais, her producer for \\"Music\\" and \\"American Life,\\" only works with her on one track. Stuart Price (aka Thin White Duke) works with her on most of the others, but there are two contributions by Bloodshy and Avant, known for their work with Britney Spears' \\"Toxic\\" and \\"My Prerogative.\\"<br /><br />The songs are as a whole, great. A lot of them sample or borrow from other artists, such as the Jacksons, the Police, and Donna Summer. She even samples herself, making this not only a pop CD but sort of a showcase of the best in music during the past few decades. What makes this CD stand out as well is that if you listen closely, the tracks tell a story. It's what she attempted to do on \\"American Life,\\" but this time, there's a more dance spin on the music and she backs off on being so personal.<br /><br />The must hear tracks are the Abba sampled \\"Hung Up,\\" the mind-boggling \\"Sorry,\\" the follow up to her old 80s song \\"Keep it Together\\" titled \\"Jump,\\" the sassy \\"How High\\" and then the best track on the album, in my opinion, \\"Push\\" which is about love and what makes a great relationship. The other tracks are good, but sort of take away from the strength of the album in some way. \\"Future Lovers\\" is weak on lyrics, \\"Isaac\\" sounds like a lost remixed Kaballah track from \\"Ray of Light\\", and the other tracks may have a great beat but they lack thoughtful, stand-out lyrics.<br /><br />\\"Confessions on a dance floor\\" is definately up there on the level of \\"Music\\" and perhaps \\"Ray of Light\\" in that there's nothing like it out there today. It takes on the subject of love like \\"Erotica,\\" it talks about relationships like \\"Bedtime Stories,\\" and it criticizes and challenges fame and fortune like \\"American Life.\\" What it does best though is that it takes you on a journey through music. If you like rap, disco, R&B or even mindless pop, this will satisfy your thirst. Each song may not be something to remember, but this CD as a whole is Madonna returning to her '80s roots and just encourages you to dance with a little push and inspiration from some great to decent music. Worth your money.Up,\\" the mind-boggling \\"Sorry,\\" the follow up to her old 80s song \\"Keep it Together\\" titled \\"Jump,\\" the sassy \\"How High\\" and then the best track on the album, in my opinion, \\"Push\\" which is about love and what makes a great relationship. The other tracks are good, but sort of take away from the strength of the album in some way. \\"Future Lovers\\" is weak on lyrics, \\"Isaac\\" sounds like a lost remixed Kaballah track from \\"Ray of Light\\", and the other tracks may have a great beat but they lack thoughtful, stand-out lyrics.  <br /> <br />\\"Confessions on a dance floor\\" is definately up there on the level of \\"Music\\" and perhaps \\"Ray of Light\\" in that there's nothing like it out there today. It takes on the subject of love like \\"Erotica,\\" it talks about relationships like \\"Bedtime Stories,\\" and it criticizes and challenges fame and fortune like \\"American Life.\\" What it does best though is that it takes you on a journey through music. If you like rap, disco, R&B or even mindless pop, this will satisfy your thirst. Each song may not be something to remember, but this CD as a whole is Madonna returning to her '80s roots and just encourages you to dance with a little push and inspiration from some great to decent music. Worth your money.

B00005JO1S|4.0|Danny (Jonah Bobo), seven years old, and Walter (Josh Hutcherson), ten, are left in the care of their older sister, Lisa (Kirsten Stewart). Dad (Tim Robbins) asks her to keep an eye on them as he runs to the office to pick up something for an upcoming meeting.  Being the teenager she is, she promptly goes back to sleep. Walter wants to watch baseball on TV, avoiding his younger brother. When Danny proves to be too much of a pest, Walter chases him throughout the house. He finds Danny hiding in the old dumb waiter and lowers him into the basement. Danny finds his way to the stairs and notices an old board game hiding between the wooden steps. \\"Zathura, a Space Adventure for Two Players\\". Danny excitedly shows the game to Walter who ignores him. Danny opens the box and turns the key on the board, causing a button to pop out. He presses the button. His spaceship is moved mechanically across the board. A card pops out. It reads \\"Meteor Shower. Take Evasive Action.\\" Danny can't read the card and shows Walter. Walter looks at the card and explains what it means just as meteors begin to destroy the living room. They soon realize that their house is floating in outer space. The only way home? To complete the game.<br /><br />\\"Zathura\\", directed by Jon Favreau (\\"Elf\\", \\"Made\\", \\"Swingers\\"), is based on a Chris Van Allsburg book, the same children's book author behind \\"Jumanji\\" and \\"The Polar Express\\".<br /><br />A well-crafted film suitable for the whole family, \\"Zathura\\" is a delight.<br /><br />The story is involving and interesting and effectively brings us into the lives of these children. As Danny and Walter run around the house, getting on each others nerves, they seem entirely realistic; two young boys, stuck inside, bored, on a Saturday afternoon. What else would they do except annoy each other, get into mischief and make various attempts to play together? As soon as they find the game, the story really kicks into gear. They realize that they have to play the game through to the end, to get their house back to its small lot in Pasadena and for everything to return to normal. As they play the game, they realize that they have to work together to overcome the challenges of Zathura.<br /><br />\\"Jumanji\\" had a similar premise, but \\"Zathura\\" is a very different film. The first film seemed overflowing with characters and animals. \\"Zathura\\" takes a different approach, telling the story of the two brothers and a couple of visitors who help out through the course of the story. Because of this, \\"Zathura\\" seems more manageable, more intimate. The first film had Robin Williams' antics, but this new film seems better, more enjoyable, more like a real adventure.<br /><br />Each card popping out of the machine signals the beginning of a new part of the adventure, a new challenge. Some of these put the two boys in dangerous situations that only strengthen the bond between them, others provide some comic relief. An early card reads \\"Player enters cryogenic sleep chamber. For next five turns.\\" Lisa (Stewart), still not realizing that the house is floating through space walks into her bathroom, concerned that she will be late for her date, and instantly freezes solid. The two boys don't know what to do, except to keep her safe until that action has expired. Another card reads \\"Rescue Abandoned Astronaut\\". At that very moment, an astronaut (Dax Shepard, TV's \\"Punked\\") flies by the front door. After they rescue him, he proves particularly useful during the remaining challenges.<br /><br />When you were a kid, you most likely played games or with toys, imagining they were real and you were actually interacting with them. \\"Zathura\\" brilliantly captures this feeling, taking it to a new level. Two little boys who were playing a real board game would probably interact in the same way. If one of the players started imagining something a little scary, the other would either encourage him to keep going, to become stronger, or help him through the challenge.The two brothers do this throughout. As various parts of the house are demolished by a robot, heat seeking aliens, and meteors, they scramble to keep the board game, their ticket home, intact.<br /><br />Director Jon Favreau does a great job at the helm. From the beautiful house, a million plus dollar Arts and Crafts home that dad (Robbins) says he is fixing up, to the look and feel of the board game, Favreau has a definite and unique style. Much like in \\"Elf\\", Favreau likes everything to seem a little retro. In \\"Zathura\\", the board game graphics and design appear to have been plucked out of the Fifties. A robot, looking more like something from \\"Forbidden Planet\\" than \\"Star Wars Episode III\\", makes an appearance. It actually looks like some of the special effects were created the old fashioned way, with models and miniature, rather than excessive CGI, lending the film a charm many parents should appreciate.<br /><br />Favreau also does a nice job with the actors. The two brothers are great. Funny and entirely believable, they could live in any house on your street. Kirsten Stewart is also very funny as Lisa, the typical teenage girl. And Dax Stewart does a nice job as the slightly charismatic astronaut.<br /><br />\\"Zathura\\" is that rare live action film good for the entire family. Kids will love it and adults will enjoy watching it. A couple of the scenes are probably too scary for some of the youngest children. Children Danny's age, under 7, will probably find the film too scary. But everyone else should have a great time playing \\"Zathura\\".challenge. The two brothers do this throughout. As various parts of the house are demolished by a robot, heat seeking aliens, and meteors, they scramble to keep the board game, their ticket home, intact. <br /> <br />Director Jon Favreau does a great job at the helm. From the beautiful house, a million plus dollar Arts and Crafts home that dad (Robbins) says he is fixing up, to the look and feel of the board game, Favreau has a definite and unique style. Much like in \\"Elf\\", Favreau likes everything to seem a little retro. In \\"Zathura\\", the board game graphics and design appear to have been plucked out of the Fifties. A robot, looking more like something from \\"Forbidden Planet\\" than \\"Star Wars Episode III\\", makes an appearance. It actually looks like some of the special effects were created the old fashioned way, with models and miniature, rather than excessive CGI, lending the film a charm many parents should appreciate. <br /> <br />Favreau also does a nice job with the actors. The two brothers are great. Funny and entirely believable, they could live in any house on your street. Kirsten Stewart is also very funny as Lisa, the typical teenage girl. And Dax Stewart does a nice job as the slightly charismatic astronaut. <br /> <br />\\"Zathura\\" is that rare live action film good for the entire family. Children Danny's age, under 7, will probably find the film too scary. But everyone else should have a great time playing \\"Zathura\\". <br />

B00080ZG10|3.0|Every genius has a price to be paid.  When the Greek mythological hero Achilles was born, he had a choice: He either could live a short glorious life or a long uneventful life.  Achilles chose the short glorious life.  In much the same way Howard Hughes made this bargain with his life it seems.  In order to accomplish the tremendous things he did with his life, the gods dictated that he had to be afflicted with out of control paranoia and obsessive-compulsive disorder.  Scorsese wisely chronicles the `glory' years of Hughes in \\"The Aviator\\" from the 20's to the 40's.  However, the crippled, broken and sick man that Hughes changed into is foreshadowed by some incredible acting by DiCaprio.  How Hughes was able to accomplish all that he did despite his mental handicap only underscores his genius.  20th Century America produced geniuses in abundance from Henry Ford to Bill Gates, but Howard Hughes could be called a Renaissance Man/Industrialist.  His interests ranged not only from aviation to movies, but also to engineering and politics.  Hughes left his stamp on everything in 1900's America from the rise of the movie industry to Watergate.  To demonstrate the relentlessness of Hughes' life, Scorsese's film speeds by at a breathless pace.  The pace of the movie is further quickened by period music and Howard Shore's incredible score.  Hughes genius is evident throughout the movie, but he also had an amazing amount of clairvoyance in the way he predicted and invested in the emerging trends of the future.  America still continues to be the global leader in movie production and is still a leader in new aviation technology.  Scorsese's Hughes does not endear himself to anyone, and the only person that seems to really care about him is Hepburn, played with uncanny precision by Blanchett.  The other person that cares about him is his operations manager, Noah Dietrich, played by John C. O'Reilly.  Dietrich acts like a surrogate father for Hughes as Howard descends into madness and paranoia.  The rest of the people around him thought of him as merely a `meal ticket.'  There have been several attempts to make a movie about Hughes, but Scorsese's attempt is the only one to make it off the ground.  For an industrialist/engineer like Hughes it is interesting that Hollywood has given him, on the whole, a positive portrayal.  This despite the fact that he was a major contributor to the Republican party.  In fact, the one time political persuasion is brought up, during the film, during the golf scene, Hughes is not even allowed to answer the question about what party he belongs to.  Another aspect of the movie is the new DiCaprio.  Early on, DiCaprio's Hughes tells Dietrich to inform the Tool Co. shareholders to call him Mr. Hughes from now on.  In much the same way, DiCaprio has certainly grown up since his more juvenile roles in \\"Titanic\\" and \\"The Beach.\\"  Some have complained that Leo was poorly cast in this movie as Hughes and DiCaprio look nothing alike.  While this may be true, I believe that DiCaprio's youthful appearance serves to emphasize what Hughes was like during the `glory' years, in contrast to the sick, twisted man he became later on in life.s and paranoia.  The rest of the people around him thought of him as merely a `meal ticket.'  There have been several attempts to make a movie about Hughes, but Scorsese's attempt is the only one to make it off the ground.  For an industrialist/engineer like Hughes it is interesting that Hollywood has given him, on the whole, a positive portrayal.  This despite the fact that he was a major contributor to the Republican party.  In fact, the one time political persuasion is brought up, during the film, during the golf scene, Hughes is not even allowed to answer the question about what party he belongs to.  Another aspect of the movie is the new DiCaprio.  Early on, DiCaprio's Hughes tells Dietrich to inform the Tool Co. shareholders to call him Mr. Hughes from now on.  In much the same way, DiCaprio has certainly grown up since his more juvenile roles in \\"Titanic\\" and \\"The Beach.\\"  Some have complained that Leo was poorly cast in this movie as Hughes and DiCaprio look nothing alike.  While this may be true, I believe that DiCaprio's youthful appearance serves to emphasize what Hughes was like during the `glory' years, in contrast to the sick, twisted man he became later on in life.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|Life isn't easy, it isn't fair and we all have to suffer through it. However, we should count our blessings, one of these blessings is Madonna and this album. (prance = pray and dance) Future Lovers is incredibly danceable, it really defies gravity. <br /> <br />Forbidden Love is a beautiful up-tempo ballad, that slows the pace of the album half way through but still doesn't damage the feel of the album. How High is another stand out track on the album, Madonna takes something personal and makes it universal (thanks to awesome beats). <br /> <br />The album comes to an end with Like It Or Not, and it does so brilliantly. How ironic is it to finish a dance album up with an acoustic guitar. <br /> <br />I Love New York's quirky lyrics take a little getting used to, the song is OK at first but it may grow on you, it certainly is growing on me. Push is an excellent track but it can get repetitive. Those two things would be my only gripe with the album. <br /> <br />I'll leave you with this. If you are a Madonna fan, this album will be one of her best if not her best album to date for you. It rivals Ray of Light in terms of quality IMO. If you like POP music, this is better than 99% of the trash being released today. If you like dance music, then bring on the glow sticks and warm up your feet, this album is MADE. FOR. YOU!!! The clubs will never sound as good as they will in the next year. Thank You Madonna for bringing joy into our life, because this is exactly what the album is, a BUNDLE OF JOY wrapped just you (and your feet).

0596000480|5.0|\\"JavaScript: The Definitive Guide\\" is not a step by step guide to JavaScript any more than an encyclopedia is a step by step guide. The book does provide an authoritative analysis of the language including a brief history of the language, data types, operators, statements, functions, objects, and arrays.<br /><br />The author does a good job of addressing some of the assumptions of the language and how these assumptions may or may not be like other languages such as C++ or Java. The author also clarifies the different levels of support for certain aspects of the language both within the discussion and with the large JavaScript reference section. The book also provides a handy and thorough W3C DOM reference for working with various aspects of DHTML.<br /><br />Some of the material in this book will provide a critical understanding to JavaScript's more advanced features. With the emergence of AJAX, many web developers are turning to JavaScript to provide solutions for dynamic web based applications. Now that JavaScript is more fully supported in modern browsers, web developers may want to turn to \\"JavaScript: The Definitive Guide\\" to enhance or polish existing JavaScript skills.<br /><br />If you are looking for a quick introduction to JavaScript, you may find yourself disappointed. However, if you are already familiar with JavaScript and need a reference to look up an answer to your problem or need a guide for fine tuning your DHTML skills, you may that this book is a rich resource for you.

0440224764|3.0|I thoroughly enjoyed the intricacies and twists in Patrick Lanigan's master plot to rip off his crooked law firm of enough money to be set for life. As someone who had gotten tired of Grisham's plot technique of using a super-powerful all-knowing company or firm who could track our hero to the ends of the earth and ruin in his life, this was a refreshing change.  Quite the opposite was true-those seeking Lanigan were perilously close to running out of money for the effort.  Also, the painstaking methods for tracking Lanigan's whereabouts were spelled out entirely for the reader, silencing even the most doubtful reader.  In many of Grisham's other books, he shirks on the plot-building duties and just tosses out a super-sleuth team that can find anyone anywhere with no explanation.<br /><br />I enjoyed the non-linear storytelling style:  the book opened with Lanigan being found by his pursuers, and then the backstory of how and why he stole the money, and how he hid from his pursuers, is filled in.  For most of the book, Lanigan looks like a \\"bad guy\\" himself, in fact.  It was a nice change-up on the way the plot was laid out.<br /><br />Many have complained about the end of the book.  I enjoyed the journey enough to trust Grisham with the end.  I'll leave all readers to make up their own mind about Lanigan's fate.
0060005696|4.0|I remember reading about ten or twelve years ago of Russian immigrants to America who were overwhelmed by the choices in the average supermarket. Accustomed to a choice of cereal or no cereal, they became paralyzed when confronted with flakes, puffs, pops, sugared or not, oat, wheat, corn, rice, hot or cold, and on and on. Now, according to Barry Schwartz, we are all overwhelmed by too many choices.<br /><br />No one is immune, he says. Even if someone doesn't care about clothes or restaurants, he might care very much about TV channels or books. And these are just the relatively unimportant kinds of choices. Which cookie or pair of jeans we choose doesn't really matter very much. Which health care plan or which university we choose matters quite a lot. How do different people deal with making decisions?<br /><br />Schwartz analyzes from every angle how people make choices. He divides people into two groups, Maximizers and Satisficers, to describe how some people try to make the best possible choice out of an increasing number of options, while others just settle for the first choice that meets their standards. (I think he should have held out for a better choice of word than \\"satisficer.\\")<br /><br />I was a bit disappointed that Schwartz dismissed the voluntary simplicity movement so quickly. They have covered this ground and found practical ways of dealing with an overabundance of choice. Instead of exploring their findings, Schwartz picked up a copy of Real Simple magazine, and found it was all about advertising. If he had picked up a copy of The Overspent American by Juliet Schor or Your Money or Your Life by Joe Dominguez and Vicki Robin instead, he might have found some genuine discussion of simple living rather than Madison Avenue's exploitation of it.<br /><br />I enjoyed the first part of The Paradox of Choice, about how we choose, but the second half, about regret and depression, seemed to drag. Fortunately, I was able to choose to skim the slow bits and move right to the more interesting conclusion, about how to become more satisfied (or \\"satisficed\\") through better decision-making.w bits and move right to the more interesting conclusion, about how to become more satisfied (or \\"satisficed\\") through better decision-making.  <br />
1568461828|5.0|A very dear friend of mine gave me a copy of Roberto Innocenti's lavishly illustrated take on Charles Dickens' \\"A Christmas Carol.\\" A holiday classic in its own right (check out the wonderful 1938 cinematic adaptation starring Reginald Owen, newly released on DVD for the first time), Innocenti's incredibly detailed watercolours bring Dickens' London to life: we peer through windows to see mothers caring for sick children, see delights piled up in shop windows, and small details that give depth to the story (the Dutch-tiled fireplace in Scrooge's home, the Cratchit threadbare hovel). The paper stock is very good quality, as is the ink. A worthwhile investment for children old enough to appreciate this timeless tale, sure to become a treasured symbol of Christmas.
B000B8QEZG|4.0|When I first heard this album I was blown away. Next to Ray of Light, this is one of her best efforts to date. Finally Madonna is back to her roots, making music that isn't trying too hard to make an overly done political message or statement. It is what it is: fun, light, self-reflective, and entertaining. However, I still felt that there were some flaws to this album. First of all, the positives.<br /><br />I like how the album begins and ends, each track keeps on going without stopping, which gives a nice disco-club experience. But the only flaw in that is that it seems to have the same repetitive rhythm, and doesn't bring much of a punch after one song to another. And even though Madonna said that there are no ballads on this album, I still felt that the only song that was upbeat and energetic was Hung Up (which is my LEAST favorite song, after awhile it becomes quite annoying). The other songs seem to be much more mellow and more in depth, like Sorry and Isaac. Now the negatives.<br /><br />I couldn't help but feel a sense of laziness on Madonna's part throughout this whole album. I understand that this is a dance album, and that they aren't meant to be the most profound and deep, but it doesn't necessarily mean that it has to be brainless! I respect Madonna for embracing her youthful spirit, regardless of the fact that she's growing to her late 40's, but sometimes I couldn't help but feel that she was trying way too hard to act like she's a 22-year old. She uses cheesy lyrics in some songs such as I Love New York (\\"other places make me feel like a dork?\\" um...ok...), and cliches like \\"sticks and stones will break by bones\\" (c'mon...). And I noticed that Madonna put a few samples of her own songs in the mix, which I thought was lazy as well. Even though this is a dance album, I honestly can't imagine any of these songs being played in a club. Madonna made it seem as if this was going to be her best dance album since her early years, but I didn't feel the groove, the vibe, or the energy. Sure, songs like Isaac had a little bit of inspiration, but nothing that brought me to my feet.<br /><br />But all in all, i think the shining star of the album is Isaac. When you listen to the song maybe you will see why. All in all, i would give this album an A for effort and creativity, but C for its overall rating. As I said before, I think Madonna tried too hard to be different. First of all, she doesn't need to prove anything at this point, and I still can't understand why she seems to constantly feel she has to prove something. And sometimes I wish Madonna would be more laid back with the promotion and hype and give us the same mature, profound album like Ray of Light, which was her best and non-forced album to date.the energy. 0812975219|3.0|Fooled by Randomness is an examination of human behavior through the prism of Wall Street and world capital markets. Mr. Taleb makes an assault on modern financial economics, as he rationalizes his work and world as an option trader.  It is an interesting and sincere book; often inspired, provocative and ambitious.  Yet, by the final chapter, confusion remains about the state of the financial world and our knowledge of it.  Readers are left no better off for facing the realities of financial markets. Ultimately, Mr. Taleb's thinking becomes diffuse, forcing him as a matter of logic to adopt a stoic resignation from what he portrays as a relatively hopeless picture of human existence.<br /><br />Since Mr. Taleb's claims about the nature of the Efficient Markets Hypothesis are erroneous, his assessment of the surrounding world is needlessly skeptical and unduly harmful to knowledge of human behavior and market institutions.  He vacillates between a rational assessment of the practical world of high finance and his own emotional reactions to the daily vicissitudes of life inside it. He makes many thoughtful observations about the limits of human rationality and the role of chance in our lives. But, he also succumbs to half truths unwittingly concocted from sketchy application of relevant literary, philosophical and scientific subjects.<br /><br />There are several valuable insights in this book, such as the retelling of Hume's \\"black swan\\" fallacy, the \\"Monte Carlo fallacy\\", the \\"signal versus noise\\" theorem and the \\"survivorship\\" bias.  But, as useful as these insights are, their probity is negated by the weak accounts of works such as that of Skinner and Tyversky and Kahneman. Mr. Taleb does not explore these subjects in a complete or methodical way.  His superficial explorations leave the impression that these works are contradictory to, rather than additive to, our maintenance of the Efficient Markets Hypothesis.<br /><br />Seen in an impartial light, the Efficient Markets Hypothesis is not an abuse of science as Mr. Taleb contends.  Through study after study, we observe repeatedly that the relative degree of efficiency in capital markets is high, conditional on the interactions of our existing (and admittedly vulnerable) worldwide institutions.<br /><br />There is no question that from time to time these institutions fail in a catastrophic way.  But, that does not mean that our provisional understanding of these same institutions is entirely incorrect.  It simply means we still have more to learn. And, since it is Mr. Taleb's business to bet against the stability of global institutions, he could have provided a more interesting tale of the battle of titans that occurs in the aggregation worldwide capital.  He could have been clearer about how he is playing a long-term game focused on systematic risks. He could have told us more of the great rewards and punishments that ride on the small margins of uncertainty and error at the center of his story.is not an abuse of science as Mr. Taleb contends.  Through study after study, we observe repeatedly that the relative degree of efficiency in capital markets is high, conditional on the interactions of our existing (and admittedly vulnerable) worldwide institutions.      There is no question that from time to time these institutions fail in a catastrophic way.  But, that does not mean that our provisional understanding of these same institutions is entirely incorrect.  It simply means we still have more to learn. And, since it is Mr. Taleb's business to bet against the stability of global institutions, he could have provided a more interesting tale of the battle of titans that occurs in the aggregation worldwide capital.  He could have been clearer about how he is playing a long-term game focused on systematic risks. He could have told us more of the great rewards and punishments that ride on the small margins of uncertainty and error at the center of his story.

Macy), and the predictably babish Dr. Eva Rojas (Penelope Cruz).  The story is fast-moving, the stakes high (saving the world, as is usual in movies like this), and the plot is only modestly cliche.  In short, as long as you don't intend to take this too seriously or seek a profound commentary on the meaning of life, the universe and everything, you're liable to have a lot of good clean fun with this movie.  Enjoy it.  I did.

B000006NXP|5.0|Kleiber's interpretation of Brahms' final symphony is the sine qua non of any classical music collection.  Brahms is part Bach part Beethoven but mostly himself. That said, his symphonies are some of the most significant accomplishments in the classical repertoire because he combined the better achievements of his two predecessors.  This Fourth is not his best, (the Third is) but Kleiber casts a spell that cannot be ignored.  Therefore, consider this one of the musical gems that you must have if only for the first movement alone.  This disc (and Tchaikovsky's Fourth by Bernstein) have been replaced more times than any others in my collection.  And every time, I only buy the Kleiber version.  Kleiber sustains the demands of Brahms from alpha to omega as few other conductors can, especially the rondo-fugue and theme-and-variations which are demanding without relent.  In toto, the Fourth lacks the organicity (intentionally so) of its predecessor pair.  That said, the first movement is the most beautiful twelve minutes of sound you will ever hear.  I could swear it were the name of God.  And you will too.

B000BGH22W|5.0|I'm frankly quite surprised at the high level of negative comments this score is receiving.  Sure, I miss John Williams, but Patrick Doyle has more than stepped up to the plate here.  This music is some of the most intense, beautiful, and massive stuff Doyle has written, and rather than merely mimicking William's themes, he creates new (yet stylistically similar) material, though he allows William's main theme to show up here and there, providing a sense of continuity.  <br /> <br />It's remarkable how varied this score is, yet how coherent it feels.  It goes from romantic (Harry in Winter) to fun (Neville's Waltz) to intensely dark (Voldemort), and never seems jarring or out-of-place.  Listen to a cue like \\"The Golden Egg\\", the orchestra's sheer power is as intense as anything this year.  The album is an astonishly good entry into the series, equalling the best of William's work, and surpassing the hack job that was \\"Chamber of Secrets\\".  The songs at the end are my only complaint, they feel completely inappropriate and out-of-place, especially \\"Do the Hippogriff\\" (which has a disturbing title, IMO).  That aside, Doyle's contribution is nothing short of fabulous, and I highly recommend the score not only to Potter fans, but to fans of film scores in general.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|In late 2005, Madonna returned with her seventeeth album, entitled Confessions On A Dance Floor. The album consisted of all-new twelve tracks, featuring the top ten hit, \\"Hung Up,\\" which topped the U.K. charts for three consecutive weeks. When the album was released, it debuted at #1 on the U.K. and U.S. charts, with 350,607 sold in the U.S., and 217,610 in the U.K. which is Madonna's biggest opening sales for any of her albums in the U.K. \\"Hung Up,\\" the first single from the album, debuted at #20 on the Hot 100 in America, but evetually climbed to #7. This gives Madonna her biggest hit since \\"Don't Tell Me\\" hit #4 in 2000. \\"Hung Up\\" has already achieved Platinum sales in the U.K. (over 500,000 copies sold), and the album has went 4x Platinum in the same place, with 1,200,000 shipments sold to date and over 1,100,000 sales. \\"Hung Up\\" has also achieved 700,000 downloads in the U.S. The second single, \\"Sorry\\", proved to be less successful, peaking at #58 in the U.S., but still stalling at #1 in the U.K. \\"Get Together\\", the third single, is already burning up airplay charts Worldwide, but only charted at #7 in the U.K. and #6 on the Bubbling Under The Hot 100 chart in the U.S. There, the album has sold 1,522,061 copies to date, and has went Platinum. Confessions On A Dance Floor went #1 in 41 countries, and has sold 8 million copies worldwide so far.     1. \\"Hung Up\\" (10/10)  2. \\"Get Together\\" (10/10)  3. \\"Sorry\\" (10/10)  4. \\"Future Lovers\\" (10/10)  5. \\"I Love New York\\" (10/10)  6. \\"Let It Will Be\\" (10/10)  7. \\"Forbidden Love\\" (10/10)  8. \\"Jump\\" (10/10)  9. \\"How High\\" (10/10)  10. \\"Isaac\\" (10/10)  11. \\"Push\\" (10/10)  12. \\"Like It Or Not\\" (10/10)    \\"Confessions,\\" dare I say, is Madonna's best studio set to date (better than \\"Bedtime Stories\\" by a bit). \\"Hung Up\\" is a great dance song, and definately gets your body moving. \\"Get Together\\" and \\"Sorry\\" are two of the albums best tracks, the latter being the second single, and the former being my favourite. \\"Future Lovers\\"and \\"I Love New York\\" are the next two tracks, the former being a better song. Some of the lyrics on NY are so bad, but you have to forgive Madonna!! \\"Let It Will Be\\" is brilliant, whereas \\"Forbidden Love\\" will be remembered for the same name on her \\"Bedtime Stories\\" (1994) album. This is a different song, and it's ten times better. \\"Jump\\" is rumoured to be the third and great single, and \\"How High\\" expresses Madonna's robotic/vocoder voice more. \\"Isaac\\" is fantastic. This seriously NEEDS TO BE HEARD! Madonna goes back to her Kallabah routes! \\"Push\\" and \\"Like It Or Not\\" end the album nicely. \\"Like It Or Not\\" is another in-your-face song, which I love about Madonna. B000002LRX|5.0|I don't mean that sacractically, this album is the most important record any band did during the entire decade.  Nirvana?  Sure, they were good at what they did, but were they original? Nope.  Pearl Jam?  Pleeeeease..  If you look at all the bands who were big around the same time Angel Dust came out (I'm talking about Soundgarden, Metallica, Guns n' Roses, etc...), they were all so much more successful than FNM because they played it SAFE.  There's nothing safe about Angel Dust, they played against type, they rocked harder, they confused and made the listener THINK, they did everything they could possibly do to make this the brilliant, unpredictable masterpiece it is.  It sounds like nothing they'd done before, and it was truly their peak. Lesser talents like Korn and Deftones took the Faith No More sound and watered it down to become the (already dead) nu metal scene in the following years, but no one can touch the original. And look at the one-time competition today.. Chris Cornell is singing Hallmark card greetings in the after-school-special pop band Audioslave, Metallica have become a disgusting parody of what they once were, Korn's run itself into the ground, the guys from GnR are making pathetic \\"rock star\\" pop with that hack Weiland, and so on..  Compare this to Mike Patton, who, aside from having 3 or 4 bands on tap at all times since FNM's demise, he's still making music no one's ever heard before, his voice and lyrics are as incredible as ever, and he's not lost one ounce of his integrity. But back to the point, Angel Dust is a MUST for any true rock fan who appreciates a band with balls and a vision.

B000BJS4OY|4.0|Those who buy this set hoping to obtain a remastered diamond, will find something similar to what they know.  The engineers have added some definition to the pieces, skimmed some strident noise off the top and cleaned up the bass. But over all, it's the same album.  An undistinguished remastering job.<br /><br />The making-of CD is fascinating and feature-length. It's probably worth the price of admission alone.<br />outer The package design is imaginative but odd. Sure, the box is sturdy, but shouldn't this event have merit some modified jewel cases instead of cardboard envelopes?  Couldn't the booklet have actually included some essays instead of some of the endless rock-archival photos that tell us very little?  Couldn't the producers have added some outtakes to the album disk, which runs under half its potential length?<br /><br />The original BTR album is an icon, and this aniversary album deserved a more arresting remastering job.

This cd represents Madonna at her best and it is her best offering to us in YEARS. I have yet to dislike a cd of hers. I even liked the \\"dreadful\\" American Life cd. It's not that I am incapable of disliking anything from her (there are certainly songs of hers that I dislike), it's just that as a whole her cds always work very well. This cd is no different. There are no less than eight stellar tracks here. Hung up, Sorry, I Love New York, Jump, How High, Isaac, Push and Like it or Not are melodic pieces of pop brilliance. The other four tracks are good, they're just not as good (IMO). There is no filler here either which is rare today. Time magazine, Billboard, MTV, NME, Rolling Stone, People magazine and US Weekly all gave this cd an excellent or good review (how can they all be wrong?).If you are a fan of Madonna (either a little or a lot) or a fan of pop/dance music you can not go wrong with the purchase of this cd.
