B000B8QEZG|4.0|Madonna has always been a major figure in not just the music industry, but pop culture as well.  As she got older, she tended to get crazier and crazier, until just recent times where she has decided to become more conservative.  That conservative nature shows on CONFESSIONS ON THE DANCE FLOOR for the simple fact that rather than going completely radical (Like the rap on the heavily criticized AMERICAN LIFE album (2003)), Madonna goes back to her roots in dance music with an album that places emphasis on the dance floor.  The biggest plus about this release is that it comes at a time where a resurgence of 1980s music for the most part is seen as great.  New wave bands have been captivating airwaves in 2005 (The Killer, The Bravery) while 80s dance-pop has seen a big resurgence (a la Gwen Stefani, Kelly Osbourne, even a less effective Ashlee Simpson on I Am Me).  CONFESSIONS, based on the resurgence of 1980s, Madonna's hey day, should have no problem going platinum, especially based upon the buzz of CONFESSIONS.<br /><br />The biggest plus of dance-pop always tends to be the production.  80s Pop was incredibly elaborate with experiments with drum programming to crazy, unfurling, driving synths.  CONFESSIONS ON THE DANCEFLOOR keeps those aspects alive as the production on the album is top notch.  Where Madonna herself doesn't make up for vocals (she has a thinner voice than some), the production fills the void.  To Madonna's credit, her vocals may be thin, but they are well performed and well produce and thin vocals are a characteristic of dance-pop music in general.  CONFESSIONS ON THE DANCEFLOOR successfully keeps the focus on dance with not true variations of that pattern on the album.  That in itself makes CONFESSIONS ON THE DANCEFLOOR a successful album.<br /><br />CONFESSIONS of course, is not without it flaws.  At times, the production tends to be a bit too sharp as well as too cluttered.  Sometimes the synths, which always sound good and fresh as well as reminiscent of the 1980s, tend to overpower Madonna's vocals (slightly on \\"Get Together\\").  When production is stripped down more (such as on \\"Let It Will Be\\"), Madonna's vocals come out of the texture better.  Where songwriting is concerned with dance-pop music, It is hard to make truly interesting songs that have some sense of depth.  As with most dance-pop albums, there are true winners here (\\"Hung Up\\", \\"Let It Will Be\\", \\"I Love New York\\", \\"Push\\", \\"Sorry\\", etc...), and there are those that are more filler material (\\"Forbidden Love\\" and \\"Like It Or Not\\").  For the most part, all of the tracks are listenable and they server their ultimate purpose of keeping the spirit of the 1980s alive.<br /><br />Personally, I think that this is a very unique album and it should fit very well in 2005, even if it is more of a comeback album, rather than true innovation on Madonna's part.  Good album.  4 stars Madonna.as reminiscent of the 1980s, tend to overpower Madonna's vocals (slightly on \\"Get Together\\").  When production is stripped down more (such as on \\"Let It Will Be\\"), Madonna's vocals come out of the texture better.  Where songwriting is concerned with dance-pop music, It is hard to make truly interesting songs that have some sense of depth.  As with most dance-pop albums, there are true winners here (\\"Hung Up\\", \\"Let It Will Be\\", \\"I Love New York\\", \\"Push\\", \\"Sorry\\", etc...), and there are those that are more filler material (\\"Forbidden Love\\" and \\"Like It Or Not\\").  For the most part, all of the tracks are listenable and they server their ultimate purpose of keeping the spirit of the 1980s alive. <br /> <br />Personally, I think that this is a very unique album and it should fit very well in 2005, even if it is more of a comeback album, rather than true innovation on Madonna's part.  Good album.  4 stars Madonna. <br />
B000002JPA|5.0|I've listened to all kinds of music, and Images & Words stands doubtlessly as arguably the best album I've ever heard.<br /><br />I've already written a review for this, but my tastes have chanegd, so I must update on it.<br /><br />While \\"Metropolis Part 2: Scenes From A Memory\\" is my personal favortie Dream Theater album, this is their all-around best album. This is also the first album I've ever heard by them.<br /><br />**Pull Me Under - The first song I've heard by Dream Theater (I saw the video for it on Headbanger's Ball). This used to be my favorite song here. I still love it. It has a memorable opening riff (which I can play on guitar), and goes into the metal song it is. I guess it has \\"that\\" ending because it's about death and death can be sudden. Anyways, this is their biggest hit song, and many fans seem to love. Still played to this day. Awesome guitar solo, as well.<br /><br />**Another Day - This song took a while for me to like. I, at first, thought it was too cheesy, and 80's. After repeated listens, and knowing what the song is about, I now love this song. Since it's about John Petrucci Sr.'s struggle with cancer, I realized the vocals couldn't be more appropriate. Beautiful song.<br /><br />**Take The Time - Another nice metal song. It starts with a keyboard intro. It then goes into what sounds like a military march drum pattern, then goes into a nice, heavy riff. This is followed by a neat keyboard solo. The opening lyrics get stuck in my head... \\"Just let me catch my breath...I've heard the promises, I've seen the mistakes, I've had my fair share of tough breaks, I need a new voice, new law, new life, take the time to reevaluate, it's time to pick up the pieces go back to suare one, I think it's time for a chaaaaaange!\\" Also, this is the only song that all the band members wrote lyrics for.<br /><br />**Surrounded - Eh. I'm not that big into this song that much. But it's still a great song! I love the keyboard intro. Catchy lyrics... \\"Dark to light, light to dark, dark to light, light to dark\\". I've read this song is about an AIDS victim (forgot the name right now). Not my favorite song here, but still great.<br /><br />**Metropolis Part 1: The Miracle And The Sleeper - Holy s**t. Those two words popped into my mind when I first heard this song. My favorite song on the album, and a top five greatest Dream Theater song for sure! Ah, where to begin... It starts out with a keyboard/guitar intro, then a drum pattern, and then it explodes into the best song on the album! The music and lyrics are powerful. After that, I breaks into the best instrumental bridge ever written. Has an amazing guitar/keyboard solo. Then it breaks into a - YES - BASS SOLO! It has great tapping! Then comes another guitar/keyboard solo. Then it breaks back into what the song was. The lyrics are amazing. \\"There must be the third and last dance, this one will last forever, Metropolis watches and thoughtfully smiles, she's taken you to her home\\". Amazing, simply brilliant. Also, as everyone else knows, this is the prequel to their concept album \\"SFAM\\", which has plenty of references to this song. Okay, I've said enough about this song. Time to move on to the next...<br /><br />**Under A Glass Moon - The heaviest song on the album. It has a keyboard intro, then goes into a drum pattern, and then a heavy guitar riff. This used to be my favorite, as well. But I still love this song! The guitar solo at the end alone is worth the album!<br /><br />**Wait For Sleep - Eh, my least favorite song on the album, It's just James LaBrie singing over Kevin Moore's piano playing. I just consider it the intro into the next song...<br /><br />**Learning To Live - Tied with Metropolis for best song on the album. At 11:30, this is the longest song on the album. It starts with a keyboard intro, a drum beat, a great, catchy guitar riff, and just into a great song. The rest of the band goes into feedback, while John Myung does a bass line with James singing \\"There was no time for pain, no energy for anger\\". This is simply amazing. I've read that this song is about the AIDS virus. Also, keep in mind this album came out in 1992, when AIDS still scared the hell out of people. This song is simply brilliant. The instrumental bridge is amazing. The guitar solo at the end is the best solo on the album, IMHO! The outro is amazing (the part with LaBrie singing \\"Woah, oh oh oh\\" or something like that). It seems so long, but the song flies on the hell by! A brilliant album closer, like \\"Space-Dye Vest,\\" \\"Trial Of Tears,\\" \\"Finally Free,\\" \\"Losing Time/Grand Finale,\\" \\"In The Name Of God,\\" and \\"Octavarium\\".<br /><br />**=Must-listen songs. Have you noticed that ALL the songs have two asterics? It's cuz they ALL rule!<br /><br />So, are you a fan of metal? CHECK!<br />Are you a fan of good music? CHECK!<br />Do you hate MTV, also for the fact that they ignore DT for bands that have no talent (*cough*chingay #1 fan*cough*)? CHECK!<br /><br />Well, then what the hell are you waiting for? 015603008X|4.0|There are those who have attempted the topic before, to show the good or ill about artificially increasing a man's intelligence, and they have all fallen by the wayside, forgotten entries in the arena of literature, all because they forgot one factor: love. <br />In Flowers for Algernon, Keyes shows us a man who is jolted out of his comfortable world of stupidity and finds his friends who were not as good as he thought they were, that all he thought was nothing more than a veiled illusion. And he copes, as everyone must, he copes and finds love and comes to term with himself. <br /> <br />Just in time for him to realize that his intelligence is only temporary. In the most heart wrenching scenes of the novel, the reader must witness his intelligence fading rapidly, each journal entry a little less exact, the spelling a tiny bit worse, until the book comes full circle and he is back where he started from, only having a wisdom that he cannot understand, or comprehend. Touching, moving, Flowers for Algernon is all that and more, it is an epic of emotion, an opera of getting what you want most and then realizing that you might have been better off. <br /> <br />

B000BISBDY|1.0|Let's be clear: any time you assemble a collection of Johnny Cash's material, you've got something good. \\"The Legend of Johnny Cash,\\" however, is nothing special. First, there's no way to capture the glory of his career in one disc. His career spanned decades. Second, there are already some very good collections: \\"The Legend\\" a four-disc set that at least offers unreleased material, and \\"The Essential,\\" a two-disc set. The \\"God, Love, Murder, Life\\" collection includes music from all points in his career. <br /> <br />As there are tons of ways to collect cashes music, the publishers of Cash's catalog need to offer fans something fresh: more unreleased tracks and alternate versions, or at least a more comprehensive collection. While \\"The Legend of Johnny Cash\\" (not to be confused with the also recently released \\"The Legend\\") does span his entire career, from Sun to American Recordings, it does so at the expense of most of his career--only 8 songs cover the decades-long period between the Sun years and American Recordings. <br /> <br />I can't think of any reason why a fan of Cash would buy this collection. If you're new to Cash, it might make a good starting point, but the other collections in this review are better starting points.

0553801503|2.0|In the first three novels in this series GRRM showed himself a master of the genre, blending character development and skillful use of language with thrilling and suspenseful plot pacing to produce page-turners that I was simply unable to put down.  In contrast, AFFC just does not manage to hook the reader.    There are too many pages spent on side characters, side scenes, subplots, that ultimately contribute little or nothing to my enjoyment.  Brienne, Dorne, Cersei should all have been condensed or moved \\"off stage\\" into other characters' chapters.  Brienne spent too much time wandering around, and her character is just not interesting enough to warrant chapters of her own.  Dorne is too scattered among different characters to form attachment to any one of them.  Cersei is moderately entertaining as she self-destructs, but she didn't warrant 10 chapters.  Part of what made Cersei an effective villain was her ambiguity; you never knew what wacky nonsense she was up to; with her secrets revealed, the evil allure is gone.    At this stage in the series, I feel GRM should be focusing on main characters.  There are certainly enough loose ends left over from the last book, that he shouldn't be opening multiple new plot threads peripheral to the story.  GRRM's strongest characters were absent from this book, and I've read his explanation for that, but ultimately, all this time spent sidetracked in AFFC detracts from the best part of the series, which lies in Jon, Dany, and Tyrion and the conflict between Ice and Fire.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|After an admirable step forward, which worked in some instances with 2003's \\"American Life\\", Madonna returns, with an eye to the future of pop, & a wink back to her earlier roots.<br /><br />I would describe this album as containing the earlier spirit of Madonna's first pop album \\"Madonna\\", with the sonic sophistication of latter records such as \\"Ray of Light\\". After Mirwais' cold electro-clash arrangements for two records, Madonna brings in Stuart Price who gives the overall record a much denser, surrounding, almost warm (in the vein of William Orbit's production for \\"Ray of Light\\") feel. Anders Bagge, Peer Astrom, Mirwais Ahmadzai, Bloodshy & Avant also lend a helping hand.<br /><br />The tracks are segued which give it a \\"non-stop\\" feel, but each spin reveals gems that definitely rise to surface after repeated listening.<br /><br />The lead single \\"Hung Up\\" a brilliant urgent slice of pop, which samples Abba's \\"Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! A Man After Midnight!\\", for it's melodic hook which plants itself within your mind on the first listen. I found it great that Madonna chose such a lesser-known Abba single to sample, something that only hardcore pop/disco/dance fans would know. Had she used \\"Dancing Queen\\" or \\"Mamma Mia\\", it wouldn't have worked.<br /><br />Other highlights include one Mirwais produced number \\"Future Lovers\\", which finds him giving homage to Giorgo Moroder's & Donna Summer's \\"I Feel Love\\" from Donna's 1977 album \\"I Remember Yesterday\\". Madonna's relaxed, sensual spoken delivery about love over shimmering melodies, we see that this ranks as one of Mirwais' finest productions for Madonna. \\"Push\\", \\"Get Together\\", & \\"Jump\\" recall Madonna's journey through pop since 1983 with dizzying effects.<br /><br />\\"Isaac\\" one of my personal favorites, is named after the male vocalist who chants on the track. In the vein of \\"Shanti/Ashtangi\\" from \\"Ray of Light\\" Madonna merges the spiritual treks of life with dance again, the results? One word: AWESOME.<br /><br />The record's lyrics work from tongue-in-cheek, \\"I Love New York\\", to her more introspective aspects. These aspects find Madonna still asking whether fame is the key to happiness on tracks such as \\"How High\\" & \\"Let It Will Be\\" the latter succeeding the previously mentioned track. \\"Let It Will Be\\" features a surging string section, that work with Madonna's somber words to deliver an all around tight package.<br /><br />Madonna has once again proven that she is the undisputed Queen of Pop, a title not given lightly. She continues to push the boundaries of mainstream pop & challenges her fans, & most importantly herself. Clapton has been known more for his ballads as of late then his guitar playing so the inclusion of \\"One Day\\" is a no-brainer. The organ tones compliment the twangy guitar tones and soulful vocals. The album's title track is a mid-tempo blues/country ditty that closes out the disc.<br /><br />The Bad<br /><br />There's a fine line between blues rock & pop rock, and it seems Clapton has officially crossed over. The music is decent, but rudimentary. We all know Clapton is capable of writing killer riffs and hooks, but on Coming Home he chooses more chord playing and soloing instead.<br /><br />The Verdict<br /><br />I just don't think that Clapton's into writing great riffs and hooks anymore. He seems to be interested in pop-rock compositions that focus more on lyrical content, commercial sound, and guest pop stars. Imagine a full album of songs that sound like \\"Change the World\\", \\"Wonderful Tonight\\", and \\"Tears in Heaven\\". That's Back Home. With his recent reunion gigs with Cream, I think fans would rather hear a full album of songs that sound like \\"Cocaine\\", \\"Layla\\", or even \\"Riding with King\\".

0451526384|4.0|All of Jane Austen's heroines are unique in different ways; Emma Woodhouse was rich and had no pressing need to marry; Fanny Price was shy and introverted; Lizzie Bennett was witty and self-mocking; and Elinor Dashwood had to share the spot-light with her younger sister Marianne. Anne Elliot's defining attribute is that she is considerably older than her literary fellows; for at the grand old age of twenty-seven is nearly past her prime (in the eyes of her contemporaries) and entering perpetual spinsterhood. In a time when a woman was defined by her society almost solely on her success in marriage, things are not looking so good for Anne.<br /><br />This is especially bitter for Anne considering she was once in love with the handsome but poor Frederick Wentworth, but persuaded to break relations between them on the advice of her deceased mother's dearest friend Lady Russell, who disapproved the match. Regretting such an action in the years that followed, Anne has almost reconciled herself to a life of maidenhood, surrounded by self-absorbed relatives.<br /><br />However, fate is about to give her a second chance. Set (and written) as the Napoleonic Wars were ending, Anne learns that Captain Wentworth - now a wealthy and respectful officer - is about to re-enter her acquaintance. After her father is forced to rent out their estate in order to pay off debts, Anne travels to Uppercross Cottage to stay with her sister Mary Musgrove, unsettled with the thought that one of the tenants left behind is the sister of Captain Wentworth. Settling in with the Musgroves and the beautiful Henrietta and Louisa (Mary's sister-in-laws), it is only a matter of time before Mr Musgrove returns with Captain Wentworth in tow.<br /><br />Anne is understandably nervous given their unhappy parting, but forces herself to remain calm and polite in his presence - and to her sorrow he behaves the same toward her, focusing his attention on the Musgrove girls. To stir things up a bit, Anne also meets her estranged cousin Mr Elliot, who is immensely attentive and charming toward her and almost certainly intends to make her his wife.<br /><br />Anne herself is neither pretty nor witty; rather she's patient, kind-hearted, sensible and part of a family that doesn't deserve her. It's not that her father and sisters are unkind, but one can feel Anne's discontent and loneliness in being part of a family that places importance only on riches and rank without any conception that their minds are weak and uninformed. As the only sensible person in a world of self-absorption, Anne trudges through her duties unnoticed and uncomplaining. But she's not perfect, for every reader knows that she's made a mistake in giving up the love of her life (though she comes to a surprising conclusion concerning it in the last chapter, placing her duty to society and family above the demands of her own heart), and as Frederick and Anne dance around each other, hopelessly trapped by the silence that conformity demands, the modern reader will share their frustration in their inability to speak their minds, especially in a world where there are no such restrictions.<br /><br />But of course, this is an Austen book and you don't have to be physic to know that a happy resolution is on its way - but the way in which it is settled is perhaps Austen's most touching union between two characters, made even more poignant by the fact that that it's taken them two tries to find one another. One feels especially happy for Anne, who truly deserves some joy in her life - her reaction to the warmth of the Musgroves' familial life is heartrending when you realise her surprise and appreciation for it is caused by the lack of such warmth in her own family.<br /><br />\\"Persuasion\\" is the shortest of all Austen's novels, as well as the last one she wrote before her death, which should appeal to those who are a bit stretched for time. It's not her best, most beloved or most famous novel, as many of the character simply aren't as vivid or involving as some of her other novels, but it contains the same themes of social commentary, verbal wit and wry insights into the human condition that Austen is famous for. A sweet, slim novel about loyal, love and second chances.of the character simply aren't as vivid or involving as some of her other novels, but it contains the same themes of social commentary, verbal wit and wry insights into the human condition that Austen is famous for. A sweet, slim novel about loyal, love and second chances.  <br />

Until one of the workers realize that there is an innocent woman stuck in the Cube. Will he stay on the evil side or will he join the good side with the prisoners? Cube was one of the most intelligent thrillers ever made, with interesting characters, awesome gore and well crafted suspense. I gave that a 10. Cube 2 was nothing. It takes a good premise (eight strangers stuck in a hypercube) but adds this alternate universe crap, with unoriginal traps, annoying characters, insulting ending and badly done CGI. In fact, too much badly done CGI. I gave that a 3 because that are some good points. The rooms are nice and the music score is not bad, but that doesn't save the movie from becoming total trash. Cube Zero is different. It wants you to ignore Cube 2 and shows you what made the original worked; suspense, good characters, well done effects and awesome gore. There are new traps this time; Acid, wires, a flesh-eating virus, sonic weapon, freezing ice and of course, a room that vaporizes the victim. Now then, the characters are very interesting. For once, you can care for the characters now. You can even feel sad for the victims that are about to die. The main character, Eric Wynn, is awesome. Of course, he's not one of the participants, but rather one of the people who watches the Cube. He has no choice, but to rescue one of the participants of the Cube. As you can see, Ernie is the writer here. No one else, but him. I love the way he explained the Cube mythology. B000B8QEZG|5.0|Ever since her debut album in `83 -- which I originally bought because it was produced by Reggie Lucas (I had no idea who the singer was) -- I've watched Madonna's career go through more ups and downs than interest rates.  After 1998's RAY OF LIGHT (IMHO her best album), I was beginning to wonder if she had any more ups left in her, despite a few good post-Y2K cuts here and there.   <br /> <br />With CONFESSIONS, UP she goes!  Although ROL is still #1 on my list, CONFESSIONS looks like it's going to solidly settle into the #2 spot.  In a move quite unique for a mainstream artist, Madonna has allowed her latest set of tracks to be compiled into a non-stop mix ... as a FIRST step in presenting this music to the public, rather than a later one.  Any of the few lapses in the lyrics that others have mentioned are minor and overshadowed by the contemporary electronica/dance sounds that at times recall disco's golden age (an ABBA sample, Donna Summer/Giorgio Moroder influences), but not to the point where the album sounds like a throwback to the past.  Any such classic elements are boomeranged via the fresh production back to 2005.   <br /> <br />Also important to CONFESSIONS' success is that Madonna's attractive vocals don't get lost in a sea of beats and electronics.  If you've liked the sound of her voice in the past, you'll be happy with it here, too.  Even if the music is dance-oriented, there is plenty of room for Madonna's vocals to take center stage.  I would expect that most -- not all, obviously -- fans of previous Madonna CDs from any point in her career will find a lot to like here.

B000002U8G|4.0|Meddle (1971.), Pink Floyd's sixth studio album<br /><br />Pink Floyd, over their long and varied career, have proven themselves to be classic/progressive rock legends. In the latter half of the 1960's, when Pink Floyd first appeared on the music scene, they amazed listeners with their unique and off-the-wall style of psychadelic rock. Following a number of successful albums, including their great debut in 'The Piper At The Gates Of Dawn', the band began to look for new styles. This was first seen with their 1970 album 'Atom Heart Mother' but more so with this album 'Meddle'. When people think of the classic sound that Pink Floyd had, they think of the music the band put out in the 1970's. 'Meddle' is regarded by many as the first album that explored this progressive style. So how good does this album measure up to be?<br /><br />'Meddle for me, is the album where the band really began to find their niche. This is the start of where the band's music really comes together - not to say that their earlier efforts aren't good - the early psychedelic albums are great but you sense that the band hadn't quite found their assured sound. 'Meddle' therefore, is the transitional album for the band and sadly because of this, the work often gets ignored in the wake of the mammoth follow up albums, 'Dark Side Of The Moon' and 'Wish You Were Here'. Given that these are perhaps the band's two best albums, it is not surprising that this album does fall in their shadows but it doesn't change the fact that this is still an awesome effort. What shouldn't be dismissed is that this album features 'Echoes; I'll mention more about it later but this IS the band's epic song and is one of their best. At half the album's length it is worth the CD's price alone. Similarly, there are classic sounding Pink Floyd tracks such as 'One Of These Days' which stand up there with great songs on their other classic albums. You can sense when listening to the album that the band are much more assured in what they are doing. The song writing is much more cohesive than on previous albums. Also the song structures make more sense than on the earlier stuff; although that's not to say the songs are simpler - Pink Floyd never follow simple song formats. Instrumentally, the band are on top form. Dave Gilmour jams out some great guitar sections and Roger Waters' bass line is assured. Rick Wright adds in plenty of keyboard effects and some clever experimental fills. Nick Mason's drumming, albeit laid back gives the ideal beat and feel to the music. The musical focus on the album was, at the time of the album's release, their best and was the ideal platform for later work.<br /><br />The layout of the album follows an unusual format, given that the second half of the work is just the one song. Side 1 of the original LP though, is a collection of 5 songs, some great, others a bit experimental and artful. The first of these is one of the band's classic efforts 'One Of These Days'. The opening whirling, windy effect is magnificent and paves the way for a gentle rolling riff from Gilmours guitar. The track gathers momentum with some clever surprise moments, perhaps the best one being when Mason, whose voice was distorted by effects murmurs 'One Of These Days I'm Going To Cut You Into Little Pieces', before an energetic surge in the music. Following this great opener is the more easy going 'Pillow Of Winds'. This song is much more acoustic with plenty of winding sections held together by some great vocals form Gilmour. 'Fearless' is next. A tranquil guitar riff again calls this one home and the 'You'll Never Walk Alone' overdub at the end of the track is an interesting addition. Next, for a more lighter and chilled out song, we have 'San Tropez'. This song is pretty funny to listen to, with an almost jazzy feel to it. Then, to round off side one we have 'Seamus'. This two minute song, written about Steve Marriott's dog is a bit weird, but still a humorous listen. A bit blues styled, the track incorporated plenty of dog barks and howls throughout.<br /><br />Then we come to the second half of the album. At 23 minutes, 'Echoes' is probably one of the longest album songs ever made. Only Pink Floyd could create a masterpiece at this length. It never gets boring or lets up an inch; this for me is perhaps the band's greatest ever song and perhaps my personal favourite epic of all time. This is the classic Floyd sound exhibition. Echoing, nautical sounds open the album with a suspicious feel and slowly the music begins to gather texture and style. Some of the lyrics are the band's best during this song, each time followed by a classic descending guitar line from Gilmour. The middle part of the song is especially great; a long section of wailing guitar exchanges with clever keyboard fills gets suddenly fazed out and then there is a tense section of more echoes. You almost feel the music wanting to burst out at you; there is so much pent up energy in tis section. Then suddenly, the music gives and there is a dreamy guitar section followed by an atmospheric verse and then a controlled but hair-raising finish with ascending wails. This track is awesome; my words can't do it justice!<br /><br />Overall, 'Meddle' was the birth of the most successful part of the band's career. Although not quite 5 star material overall, due to a few weak areas on the first half of the album, the all-time epic 'Echoes' is a winner for this album. This album is indeed the building block and more than deserving predecessor to 'Dark Side Of The Moon' and deserves plenty of praise. Any fan wanting more of the 'classic' Floyd sound of the 1970's should definitely invest in this great album.<br /><br />MY RATING: 8.5/10plenty of dog barks and howls throughout.    Then we come to the second half of the album. At 23 minutes, 'Echoes' is probably one of the longest album songs ever made. Only Pink Floyd could create a masterpiece at this length. It never gets boring or lets up an inch; this for me is perhaps the band's greatest ever song and perhaps my personal favourite epic of all time. This is the classic Floyd sound exhibition. Echoing, nautical sounds open the album with a suspicious feel and slowly the music begins to gather texture and style. Some of the lyrics are the band's best during this song, each time followed by a classic descending guitar line from Gilmour. The middle part of the song is especially great; a long section of wailing guitar exchanges with clever keyboard fills gets suddenly fazed out and then there is a tense section of more echoes. You almost feel the music wanting to burst out at you; there is so much pent up energy in tis section. Then suddenly, the music gives and there is a dreamy guitar section followed by an atmospheric verse and then a controlled but hair-raising finish with ascending wails. This track is awesome; my words can't do it justice!    Overall, 'Meddle' was the birth of the most successful part of the band's career. Although not quite 5 star material overall, due to a few weak areas on the first half of the album, the all-time epic 'Echoes' is a winner for this album. This album is indeed the building block and more than deserving predecessor to 'Dark Side Of The Moon' and deserves plenty of praise. Any fan wanting more of the 'classic' Floyd sound of the 1970's should definitely invest in this great album.    MY RATING: 8.5/10
B00006RCSR|5.0|Andy Tennant's retelling of the classic Cinderella story by the Brothers Grimm (no pun intended on the movie of the same name) is a classic period film. Drew Barrymore (\\"E.T.\\") is still impressive and beautiful as Danielle, a young girl in 17th century France who inadvertently catches the attention of the crown prince (Dougray Scott) while slaving away for her evil stepmother (Academy Award winner Angelica Huston). An awesome score by George Fenton (who would reunite with Andy Tennant to score \\"Anna And The King,\\" a non-musical version of the classic Rodgers&Hammerstein musical \\"The King And I,\\" with Tennant again behind the director's chair). This is one of my all-time favorite period movies. I fell in love with Ms. Barrymore when I saw the promotional advertising for this movie; I was 8 years old at the time...and I fell in love all over again at 19.  Rated PG for some thematic elements and mild language.

B000002U82|5.0|Dark Side Of The Moon (1973.), Pink Floyd's eighth studio album<br /><br />There has never been and never will be a band quite like Pink Floyd. Over their extensive career, the prog. rock quartet of Dave Gilmour (guitar), Roger Waters (bass), Rick Wright (keyboards) and Nick Mason (drums) have made a legendary contribution to rock music (I've also not forgotten original frontman Syd Barratt in that list). The band tried out more than their fair share of new ideas and in many ways paved the way in pushing the boundaries of music. All of the band's albums are quite popular, but none more so than 'Dark Side Of The Moon' which is heralded as the Floyd's greatest work and one of the greatest albums of all time. This album has shifted more units than any other rock album ever made (sales are over 40 millions units I think!). So is this album really deserving of its great popularity and also, why is it just that bit special?<br /><br />For me, there is no question, this is Pink Floyd's ultra-definitive album and also their finest album - other hardcore Floyd fans may disagree and choose 'Wish You Were Here' or 'The Wall' by preference but I think that this tops them both. Pink Floyd, up to this point had amazingly demonstrated their great potential, none more so than in their great 1971 release, 'Meddle'. With that album, you could sense that the band were on the brink of producing a true masterpiece and here you have it, the ultimate masterpiece from the band in 'Dark Side Of The Moon'. Everything comes together on this album; the songs run cohesively and perfectly from one to the next and the songwriting is literally awesome. It should come as no surprise that all of the band members had songwriting inputs on the album (rather than the sole Waters dominance that would come in later albums) and this further demonstrates why this album is so good. It often amazes me that there are people around today who are more than willing to bash this album. I constantly hear comments such as 'It sounds dated' or 'This music makes me fall asleep'. These people (probably listeners to senseless nu metal, emo crap or anything else thats abysmal in music in recent times) never fail to amaze me; I don't know what stuff they must be on to make them so diluded! At my last check, this album was made over 30 years ago ... YES 30 YEARS. People are quick to diss the techniques that Pink Floyd used on this album to make various effects but at the time it was completely new and revolutionary - they didn't have the latest digital recording studio to help them out! That aside, the various styles the band use on the album for me still sound fantastic and fresh. Gilmour's guitar work is first rate, as are his vocals. Waters' bass play is beautifully resonant throughout and the keyboard work by Wright is fantastic. With that all aside, it is the lyrical concept that really makes this album so good. Pink Floyd take you through an amazing conceptual journey on this album, and one that you never tire of. The all too realisitic themes of loss of time, war, madness and death are in this album. The band tackle a whole load of themes in this 40 minute album; you can't not be emotionally moved by it. This is why the album has appealed to so many over time; the album's concept driven, experimental but ultimately polished and structured style is what makes it shine so much. The album has so many sides to it and you notice something new with every listen. Who also could miss the cover; the prism effect front is simple but an amazing eye-catcher.<br /><br />The journey of the 'Dark Side Of The Moon' begins with opener 'Speak To Me/Breathe'. The opening part of the song opens up with a showcase of the effects to come; mad voices, a woman screaming, cash tills and everything else all cleverly mix together (note all the voices you hear on the album were workers at the recording studio who had their reponses recorded when they were asked about madness). This then runs into the start of the proper music, firstly with the classic guitar and bass line for the album followed by a couple of verses of harsh and brutal lyrics. 'On The Run', is a clever track with a racing electronic sound which was created by speeding a note sequence on a tape loop - there's plenty more effects added in on this track. Then we come to the album's first epic in 'Time'. A surpise entrance of ringing bells kick starts this one. Gilmour's crunching guitar chords alongside some echoing drumming give this song an atmospheric build up. This then becomes a lyrically amazing song, with themes on time slipping away and growing old. Gilmour's guitar solo is brilliant; as is the 'Breathe' (reprise) song exit. Following this great track is the closing song for side one with 'Great Gig In The Sky'. Rick Wright's gentle piano chords are superbly contrasted by the passionate, emotional and evocative wails by singer Clair Torry, who the band hired for the song. The song is like nothing I've heard before.<br /><br />The second half of the album opens with the album's most famous song. Who could fail to recognise the unique cash-machine sounds at the start of the song. Rhythmically, this song is weird as it is written in 7/4 time, as opposed to the 4/4 standard. However, this time signature paves the way for the songs classic bass line. The lyrics, based around corporate wealth, greed and acquisition are classic, as is the middle section with plenty of roaring guitars. 'Us And Them' follows; perhaps the album's most heartfelt song. Based on the theme of outrage at the continuation of the Vietnam war, this song is powerful. The keyboard work is imaginitive and the saxophone solo is brilliant. 'Any Colour You Like' is next. This one is experimental where Gilmour tries his hand at some quirky guitar play over some great keyboard dubs. The madness theme of 'Brain Damage' is next up which looks at the mental damage caused to war casualties. This is another foreboding song with a brutal and realistic edge. Finally, to close this epic album is 'Eclipse'. A short, punchy finish with plenty of contrasting lyrics building to a climax. The heartbeat at the end cleverly trails the album to a finish, in the style just like it began.<br /><br />'Dark Side Of The Moon' is an epic musical journey through the tragedies of life. Pink Floyd were at their absolute peak with this album and the work is never short of inspired moments. This album is perfect; everything comes together both musically and lyrically. Plenty of people have this album but still, if you don't then this is a MUST buy. This album is not just the place to begin a Pink Floyd collection, it is the place to begin a good music collection in general. Trust me, and all the other high rated reviews for this album, this album is well worth the money you will pay for it and the time you will spend listening to it! (excuse the puns!)<br /><br />EXTRA NOTE: 'Dark Side Of The Moon' was issued in an SACD format some time ago. If you have the technology for SACD formats then this is the version you may want to get. I personally don't know what the quality is like with that version and I've heard a mixture of positive and negative feedback alike about it.<br /><br />MY RATING: 10/10; a classic that rises above the restfirstly with the classic guitar and bass line for the album followed by a couple of verses of harsh and brutal lyrics. 'On The Run', is a clever track with a racing electronic sound which was created by speeding a note sequence on a tape loop - there's plenty more effects added in on this track. Then we come to the album's first epic in 'Time'. A surpise entrance of ringing bells kick starts this one. Gilmour's crunching guitar chords alongside some echoing drumming give this song an atmospheric build up. This then becomes a lyrically amazing song, with themes on time slipping away and growing old. Gilmour's guitar solo is brilliant; as is the 'Breathe' (reprise) song exit. Following this great track is the closing song for side one with 'Great Gig In The Sky'. Rick Wright's gentle piano chords are superbly contrasted by the passionate, emotional and evocative wails by singer Clair Torry, who the band hired for the song. The song is like nothing I've heard before.    The second half of the album opens with the album's most famous song. Who could fail to recognise the unique cash-machine sounds at the start of the song. Rhythmically, this song is weird as it is written in 7/4 time, as opposed to the 4/4 standard. However, this time signature paves the way for the songs classic bass line. The lyrics, based around corporate wealth, greed and acquisition are classic, as is the middle section with plenty of roaring guitars. 'Us And Them' follows; perhaps the album's most heartfelt song. Based on the theme of outrage at the continuation of the Vietnam war, this song is powerful. The keyboard work is imaginitive and the saxophone solo is brilliant. 'Any Colour You Like' is next. This one is experimental where Gilmour tries his hand at some quirky guitar play over some great keyboard dubs. The madness theme of 'Brain Damage' is next up which looks at the mental damage caused to war casualties. This is another foreboding song with a brutal and realistic edge. Finally, to close this epic album is 'Eclipse'. A short, punchy finish with plenty of contrasting lyrics building to a climax. The heartbeat at the end cleverly trails the album to a finish, in the style just like it began.    'Dark Side Of The Moon' is an epic musical journey through the tragedies of life. Pink Floyd were at their absolute peak with this album and the work is never short of inspired moments. This album is perfect; everything comes together both musically and lyrically. Plenty of people have this album but still, if you don't then this is a MUST buy. This album is not just the place to begin a Pink Floyd collection, it is the place to begin a good music collection in general. Trust me, and all the other high rated reviews for this album, this album is well worth the money you will pay for it and the time you will spend listening to it! (excuse the puns!)    EXTRA NOTE: 'Dark Side Of The Moon' was issued in an SACD format some time ago. If you have the technology for SACD formats then this is the version you may want to get. I personally don't know what the quality is like with that version and I've heard a mixture of positive and negative feedback alike about it.    MY RATING: 10/10; a classic that rises above the rest
B000AJJNPY|5.0|The songs from their last album had no titles, the record before that was promoted with a video featuring dancing Down's Syndrome sufferers and this release was forebodingly titled Final Album on early promotional copies sent to media. Iceland's Sigur Ros could never be accused of following an orderly routine, but were Takk to actually signal their imminent demise then what a breathtaking way in which to bow out. Takk once again finds the Arctic-dwelling post-rock outfit wrapping up their conjectural muse within a special package - this time taking on a bookish form even more elaborate than Radiohead's similar Amnesiac project. Featuring elaborate line drawings, embossed leaves and delicate stencils, Sigur Ros's arty sleeve design is a fine fit for their provocative, inspiring and exhilarating music.  <br />While Jonsi Birgisson's lyrics remain as intangible and confounding as the Australian public's love of Rove McManus, the delicate and graceful sounds of Takk are at their best when absorbed as a whole. Listening to a single Sigur Ros album tune is akin to only watching 10 minutes of Citizen Kane - it's a grand masterpiece there to be worshipped in its entirety, not in brief flashes.  <br />The repeated phrases and cyclical effects of () are present yet less obvious this time around, instead replaced by horns on Saeglopur, upbeat moments on Anduari and more commercial possibilities than previous outings. When the final note of closer Heysatan rings out, there remains an air of expectation that something will follow. Although a postscript never arrives, Takk hopefully only closes the latest Sigur Ros chapter rather than marking the conclusion of the Icelandic post-rockers' whole book.

B000B8QEZG|2.0|Madonna appears damn confident that Confessions On A Dance Floor is the hottest dance album she's created in her three decades of recording. The accompanying press release for the record finds the 47-year-old brashly remarking \\"I want people to jump out of their seats!\\", yet the only time listeners will abide will be when they're getting up and turning off the stereo upon realisation that Confessions On A Dance Floor is one of Madonna's weakest releases ever.   <br />She's racked up 200 million albums, almost 50 Top 40 singles and 20 MTV Awards, so why does Madonna's Confessions On A Dance Floor fail to engage listeners to the level of her earlier successes? It seems that by calculatedly creating a dance album where each track segues into the next, the variety exuded by her finest albums Like A Prayer, Ray of Light and Music has been dismissed in favour of releasing an album that soon becomes stale and samey. <br />The ABBA-pilfering hook, sublime vocal layers and Visage bassline of Hung Up were an awesome introduction to Confessions On A Dancefloor, proving to be Madonna's hottest lead-off single for an album since Frozen pre-empted Ray Of Light in 1998. Unfortunately, apart from the multilingual throb of Sorry, the slinky groove of Push and the Giorgio Moroder electro undulations of Future Lovers, the album is a disappointing shadow of Miss Ciccone's greatest moments. <br />How High reuses her string arrangements from Die Another Day and combines them with an intro that sounds eerily like Lipps Inc's Funky Town, while Get Together could worryingly pass as a limp remix of The Spice Girls' 2 Become 1. Worst of all is I Love New York, where Madonna's lyrical use of the word dork ensures it usurps her use of the line `feeling super-duper' in her American Life rap while simultaneously delivering another ingratiating US city song. <br />Madonna remains a music icon rightly deified for her pop nous, marketing skills and progressive attitude, but her latest album fails tore-establish her position after American Life saw her stumble. Sorry Madonna, but your latest music won't make the people come together.

It is an interesting story, but I feel that the story could have been written better and become somewhat of a mystery novel. B000002WPI|5.0|Wow , Thats all i can say when it comes too the Debut of the Wu-Tang Clan in \\"36 Chambers\\" This LP was just Amazing , no exageration , Every single member of this crew can Rap like no other , each member have there own unique style which makes the Wu-Tang Clan so great. Flor (Paz Vega)  speaks no English but is determined to build a good life for her daughter Christina (Shelbie Bruce). She accepts a housekeeping job at the home of a dysfunctional couple (Sandler and Tea Leoni, who gives an excellent performance as Sandler's crazy, selfish wife). Flor must contend with her new employer's hostility toward her own family and her unwanted influence on Christina. \\"Spanglish\\" is a heartwarming movie about love, family, and responsibility. B000001G5H|5.0|I'd imagine that anyone serious about the solo piano repertoires owns several recordings of these Etudes and probably has given Mr. Pollini's at least a spin. If you're new to this, Pollini has a substantial reputation as a pianist and many of his other recordings have garnered praise. Judging from the hubbub here with these reviews you'll quickly learn that there are two teams battling around this composer, and they tend to represent emotion versus intellect. This is a tough issue with Chopin as the composer himself gave indications he wanted to be considered a \\"classical\\" (that's \\"intellectual\\" but even that's questionable) composer. Some of this music, played \\"classically\\" may have struck his contemporaries as romantic nontheless. It's all discussions about angels dancing on heads of pins. <br /> <br />Some think Pollini's approach is too intellectual, meaning he downplays the schmaltz...perhaps, I'm never sure. OK, these are not the dreamiest performances maybe--I wouldn't use them for a hot-tub seduction--but they're really spectacular anyway; his technique is incredible. The first Etude that one reviewer here hated took my breathe away with its precision and dramatic sweep. The rest of the disc is great. I think anyone new to this music would be very happy with this disc. <br /> <br />What's bugging me these days about what we're doing here, and why I think I'll bag out of doing it anymore, is that, well, on one hand we've got Pollini, a world-renowned pianist who is known for his interpretive thoughfulness and Frederic Chopin who seems to be widely regarded as a composer of top notch music. Then there's me--a complete nobody with a PC and an internet connection--and some guy from East Butthead, and some other guy from Nowheresville, all pontificating on a great pianist and a great composer like we're some sort of world-class experts, which none of us really can be because this isn't a science. It's mostly opinion and history has shown that even \\"expert\\" opinion is often badly skewed. Just ruminate on all the advanced degree holders in Germany who thought Hitler was a whiz-bang. <br /> <br />This music is supposed to be entertaining, it should be fun, it should enrich our lives. It's not tasteless low-fat ice cream, or soy milk, or daily exercise. The whole classical music shtick has been weighted down by over-opinionated students and grumpy over-opinionated middle-aged men who seem to think that there's only one way to do something--reminds me of a pig-headed uncle I once had, the sort of guy who used only one--the correct--pattern to mow the lawn. Sometimes I think we should just watch for mediocrity (and even that's a matter of opinion) or plain old incompetence. My view is that it's just best to share what we think is special; share our enthusiasm for a piece, a performance, and ditch the portentious mudslinging. Sadly, most of these recordings we crank about probably won't even be in print in ten years.  <br /> <br />Maybe,hopefully, some future generation will rediscover all this great music, see it fresh, and bring the sense of awe and wonder back to it that it deserves.
0393327655|4.0|Passing in Review<br /><br />\\"The End of Faith:  Religion, Terror and the Future of Reason\\" by Sam Harris<br /><br />Review by M. Vince Turner<br /><br />November 2005<br /><br />Author Sam Harris takes a no-holds-barred assault on religion in his book The End of Faith.<br /><br />Harris' assault is, however, is not vindictive.  Like a finely sighted assault weapon, Harris picks his targets carefully and hits a bull's eye with each salvo against organized religion and the le-gions that come together to form organized religion.  Christians, Jews and Muslims do not es-cape his sights.  Harris takes on this subject with righteous aplomb, ripping away the veil of sanctimonious cover that has shielded each religious sect so affectively for too long.<br /><br />As an ordained minister, I found much of The End of Faith right on target.  Harris elaborates myriad aspects of organized religion that have come to make too much religion the enemy of God rather than being the advocate of God among groups that lay strong claim to \\"their\\" God.<br /><br />At times Harris applies near-surgical skill, pulling away the cancerous flesh that clothes so much of religion today and he shows how religious praxis has created too much harm in this world and how religion continues to do so.  The End of Faith is not a book that will be well-received by the self-righteous Christians, so many of whom assert \\"their\\" God is the only God and that their \\"God\\" accepts only certain people or certain groups within this cosmos we call Earth.<br /><br />That is not to suggest I agree with every thing Harris writes, but I admit to agreeing or concur-ring with a larger portion of this book.  Harris stresses the importance and significance of spiri-tuality and mysticism, which in Christian faith is where the heart of Jesus of Nazareth fully re-sides.  Harris challenges the notion that the Christian God is better than the Muslim God, or the Jewish God trumps the others or is trumped by the others.  The sacredness of God is dimin-ished by the ways Holy Scripture is misinterpreted in order to meet and support political objec-tives and ends.  Which among us truly holds possession of the \\"right\\" God?<br /><br />Harris points without timidity at how the God of Muslims is violent and how Muslims put that violent God into action.  Yet, Christians are called to face that same ferocity of God as practiced in modern day America.  They are then challenged to ask themselves if this is really the way \\"their/our\\" God wants us to act.  No one's God gets off Scot-free in The End of Faith.<br /><br />The End of Faith will get little support from those Christian groups today who see America as God's chosen nation, God's new empire.  The End of Faith will raise the ire and hackles of those who believe they have all the right answers, unwilling to be open to other points of view.<br /><br />The sad tale of the Sadducees and the Pharisees of Jesus' time is resurrected, and we see those sects alive and well in today's world creating the same arrogance, intolerance, nationalism and destruction they created two millennia ago.  The End of Faith offers objective criticism of relig-ion and details how much of religion has offered less benevolence and benignity to the world while offering up more vengeance, vindictiveness and destruction all \\"in the name of God\\".<br /><br />For those interested in seeing religion painted with an unvarnished eye, I strongly recommend The End of Faith.  It will challenge many of today's believers, but that is after what Jesus of Nazareth was attempting in His own time.  Those Christians who recall that the first Christians were referred to as \\"The People of the Way\\" will learn from The End of Faith how we have fallen away from that \\"way\\".  Those bold enough to read The End of Faith should come away feeling enlightened, although that \\"enlightenment\\" may prove troubling.f God is dimin-ished by the ways Holy Scripture is misinterpreted in order to meet and support political objec-tives and ends.  Which among us truly holds possession of the \\"right\\" God? <br /> <br />Harris points without timidity at how the God of Muslims is violent and how Muslims put that violent God into action.  Yet, Christians are called to face that same ferocity of God as practiced in modern day America.  They are then challenged to ask themselves if this is really the way \\"their/our\\" God wants us to act.  No one's God gets off Scot-free in The End of Faith. <br /> <br />The End of Faith will get little support from those Christian groups today who see America as God's chosen nation, God's new empire.  The End of Faith will raise the ire and hackles of those who believe they have all the right answers, unwilling to be open to other points of view. <br /> <br />The sad tale of the Sadducees and the Pharisees of Jesus' time is resurrected, and we see those sects alive and well in today's world creating the same arrogance, intolerance, nationalism and destruction they created two millennia ago.  The End of Faith offers objective criticism of relig-ion and details how much of religion has offered less benevolence and benignity to the world while offering up more vengeance, vindictiveness and destruction all \\"in the name of God\\".   <br /> <br />For those interested in seeing religion painted with an unvarnished eye, I strongly recommend The End of Faith.  It will challenge many of today's believers, but that is after what Jesus of Nazareth was attempting in His own time.  Those Christians who recall that the first Christians were referred to as \\"The People of the Way\\" will learn from The End of Faith how we have fallen away from that \\"way\\".  Those bold enough to read The End of Faith should come away feeling enlightened, although that \\"enlightenment\\" may prove troubling. <br />
0553801503|3.0|Well, Ross Blackman has pretty well expressed my thoughts on this, and so have others, but I'll pile on anyway. <br /> <br />First of all:  Maybe it's just the fact that I had put this series aside for so long, and am coming to it with fresh eyes, but Martin's writing style and characterization really isn't all that good.  His writing style is very effective at dragging you in and making you want to continue, largely I suspect due to his habit of strong opening sentences, ending chapters on cliffhangers, and throwing in surprise twists, but these tricks do not a deep piece of literature make.  (For example, I got very tired of sentences like \\"The dead men sat up.\\"  That might have been a strong and shocking opener the first dozen or so times he used it, but after that, it kinda loses its effect.)   <br /> <br />Second, Martin has (at least for me) a real difficulty at conveying emotional tone in his writing.  I seem to recall that he worked in television for a while, and if so, maybe that's why--as a TV writer, he wouldn't have to convey emotional tone, because the actors would do it for him.  He introduces scenes, situations and characters that *should* be deep and have emotional resonance, and yet somehow he can't realize it.  I'm not sure whether he even understands the potential depth of the situations he creates, let alone has the ability to convey it.  This inability (for me) to convey emotional tone, coupled with the melodramatic levels of violence and misfortune that happen to his characters, sort of leads to the feeling that he doesn't really care about his characters--and if the author doesn't even care, then why should I? <br /> <br />Third:  Speaking of levels of violence, how about that Biter, huh?  Martin here continues a trend I noticed about as far back as the first book, which is almost a fetishization of images of death, gore, violence, suffering and decay.  There are times when high levels of violence and gothic imagery can be used appropriately--for example, to induce certain psychological effects in characters, or to make philosophical or emotional points (see for example Stephen R. Donaldson's writing--he very often uses dark and grim themes to excellent allegorical and symbolic effect), but in order for that to be the case, there has to be something you're trying to say with it.  In Martin's case, there isn't, at least not that I can see; it's nothing more than sensationalism and cheap melodrama.  In which case, someone really needs to tell him to use this stuff *sparingly*--splash too many buckets of blood around, and it loses its effect. <br /> <br />Fourth:  Editing, editing, editing!  A lot of what is in here really did not need to be here, IMO.  Others have made this point too, but it's a good one that should be restated.  Case in point: the ironmen's assault on the north.  This is something that could have been described in a few sentences; we didn't really need to be shown it.  Double-ditto for the Dornish scheming.  There was actually a heck of a lot of repetition and circular plotting here, as well.  A  lot of the \\"new\\" characters he introduces didn't need to be here, and seemed quite similar to each other as well--following a pattern of \\"New Character X, who has Y traumas/issues in his background that cause him to take plot-furthering action Z.\\" (Psst!  Hint for aspiring writers:  When creating new characters, a cheap 'n' easy way to create the illusion of \\"depth\\" is to implant a trauma in their background.  Double points if it has to do with love, and triple points if it's a dead love interest!)   <br /> <br />Four-a:  Just to add to the Cersei pile, I really did not need that many chapters of watching Cersei follow exactly the path I had predicted she would follow all the way from the single chapter he had included at the end of Storm of Swords.  At least if he had made her a competent ruler who rules well and then, on the last page of the book, had her suddenly drop dead from a heart attack,it would have been more interesting; my level of surprise at watching what he wrote for her here was exactly zero.  Wow.  Character X behaves exactly the way I thought s/he would.  What a surprise.  And yes, her prophecy did come across as tacked-on.  If it was something he had dreamed up for her from the get-go, then he should have done a better job of foreshadowing it in the other books.  (Btw:  I'll bet a million bars of gold-pressed latinum it's Jaime who ends up killing her rather than Tyrion--Cersei's a minute older than Jaime, so he also qualifies as her \\"little\\" brother, and it's exactly the sort of non-shocking \\"shocker\\" twist that I would expect.) <br /> <br />Five: Repetition is not your friend!  How many groups of nobles are there out there scheming against each other?  And all the scheming is exactly the same.  Wow, X group of nobles wants marriage/revenge/the throne, etc. so they will take Y action to achieve Z goal!  Maybe that's why he introduced Brienne as a POV character--to get away from all the politics for a bit.  Nevertheless, the political manuevering is something that he should look into cutting way back on from now on.  And if it wasn't political manuevering it was religious manuevering, what with Balon running around drowning men, and R'hllor, and the the High Septon, and so on.  Again, too many plot threads, and all of them far too similar.  I also agree completely that Martin is starting to get *way* too into the heraldry and genealogical relationships of his world, to the point that it's starting to cut into his narrative.  I'm having terrifying flashes of Jordan and clothing details, a la Crossroads of Twilight. <br /> <br />Now are there things Martin does well?  Absolutely, of course. His writing style, as I mentioned previously, is very effective at drawing you in and making you want to continue.  His description and scene-setting is excellent, as always, and he *also* does a very good job of differentiating his various locations from one another (for example, Dorne felt like a convincingly different place than King's Landing, which feels convincingly different from the Riverlands, which feels convincingly different from the Iron Islands, and so on.)  And of course, there are those who would argue that \\"this is a transitional book.  Martin is laying the groundwork for some stuff that's really going to pay off down the line.  Just have faith.\\"  The problem with that argument is that I've been down that road before with Robert Jordan, who's been stuck on \\"transitional\\" for something like seven books now, and even as the books decline in quality, the pay-off just never seems to come.  (And the decline started very close to the same place too, btw, and shared some of the same features, including an over-emphasis on scheming and politics at the expense of plot and proliferation of unnecessary sub-plots that served no purpose other than to drag out the story.) What with Martin's series expanding from three books originally, to six, then to seven (and I've heard whispered rumors that it's actually going to be eight), combined with the proliferation of plotless plots, of characters we didn't need to see, of emphasis on heraldry and lineage, I'm having horrible feelings that I've seen this pattern before.  Martin's certainly not as bad as Jordan *yet,* but the emphasis is on the \\"yet.\\"  I hope Dance with Dragons gets things moving again.

B000B8QEZG|5.0|Ray of Light was undoubtedly Madonna's greatest album.  It featured her most profound lyrics, her vocals strengthened, it had a real atmosphere to it and some of the coolest experimental sounds to come from a pop icon.  Since that album, being her most experimental, it seems like she's struggled to push her way back into the mainstream.  Music was a good album because Mirwais suits her new style very well and the effects and euro-disco synths complimented it and made the album sound almost like an entirely new style of dance/trip-hop altogether.  American Life was far too similar to Music, only it was a hollow album.  Where Music had its strong points with powerful euro-disco tracks and a real sense of late-night adventure - American Life was lacking anything to give the music any depth.  Basically it sounds like the offcuts of Music, recycled and re-molded into a lacklustre left-wing political effort.  Thankfully Madonna's now chosen to ditch the entire thing and head in yet another direction.  It's nothing new for Madonna to make a dance album considering her roots - but she has never done it quite like this.  Instead of sugary pop, she has a more aggressive presence here.  The lyrics are still somewhat simple but that comes with the dance territory - plus, with that in mind, they're a lot more meaningful than most other commercial dance tracks.  The music is absolutely amazing, very funky.  At times melancholy, exotic then back to 70s disco reinvention.  This beats both Music and American Life.

B000BJS4OY|5.0|Born To Run is the album that took Bruce Springsteen from a struggling recording artist who was almost dropped by his label to simultaneous covers of Time & Newsweek. The production has a big sound to it. On some songs it sounds like a hundred instruments are playing. Bruce wanted a Phil Spector Wall of Sound feel and the album achieves that goal. Jon Landau, his future manager, said after seeing Bruce in concert in 1974 that \\"he just saw the future of rock 'n' roll\\". Born To Run helped fulfill that prophecy.  Finally, Sony offers a remastered version of the album which one of first to be released on cd in the late 80's.  The sound quality is superb and the big sound of the album comes through beautifully.  It would have been enough to just have a remastered cd, but this set ups the ante with two DVDs.  The first is a full concert from the Hammersmith Odeon in London and it shows a skinny, bearded Boss showing off why his live shows from that era are legendary.  The second DVD is a documentary detailing the making of the album and it contains all the key players including Ernest \\"Boom\\" Carter who drummed on the title track as well as an integral part of the early E Street Band, keyboardist David Sancious.  On top of all that, you get a great booklet that contains unreleased photos.  It would be great if Sony takes this approach with other albums in Mr. Springsteen's catalog as this treatment is long overdue for an artist of his stature.os. 0553801503|5.0|Great feasts, especially the vast ones of high fantasy, are an affair of multiple senses and motives where the convoluted journey through myriad courses can leave the literary diner not merely full, but profoundly changed. And no more so than in A FEAST FOR CROWS, George R. R. Martin's fourth and latest in his ever-expanding saga, A Song of Ice and Fire.    If you count a tantalizing preview of the upcoming A DANCE WITH DRAGONS --- which picks up the massive FEAST's abruptly truncated threads --- and the very necessary appendices listing principal movers and shakers among the families vying for control of his fictional Westeros, you're in for an 800-page ride through the amazing geography of Martin's imagination.    Now I have to admit early on that I didn't really have time this month to delve into a book this size, and opened it thinking (naively) that I could jump out and resume \\"normal\\" life whenever I wanted. I can already hear the rueful laughter of hardcore Ice and Fire fans. Yes folks, you're right; the strange convoluted beauty and visceral energy of Westeros imposes its own \\"normal\\" on anyone who steps through the thin places of our universe into its realm. After only a few hours in that world, I too could see the map of Westeros every time I closed my eyes and could place more and more features onto it without flipping back and forth to the inside covers!    Strangely enough, that amazing power of Martin's prose to weave the reader into its unfolding fabric doesn't include waves and waves of overt magic and mystery, nor even (in this epic segment, at least) the advent or return of magical great beasts. For sure, there's talk of dragons and sorcery, and you do get the odd simmering potion wafted about here and there, but compared to the vibrant presence of characterization, superb dialogue and plot-building, these more conventional aspects of high fantasy are often just supporting elements.    That may sound rather heretical, but once you've traveled a fewpages into the varied quests, flights, machinations and yearnings of Martin's distinctive characters, they quickly develop memorable texture and substance of their own. Martin achieves this in part through his consummate skill in wielding the point-of-view approach, so that the reader --- more fly on the castle wall than omniscient --- becomes wholly invested in their individual fates and futures. Some previous characters in the Westeros saga (the high profile Jon Snow being one to note) never step onto the stage except in conversation, while others who bided their time in the wings through earlier cataclysms (like the fully drawn Brienne of Tarth) emerge to fill the instrumental spaces left by the dead and disappeared.    It almost goes without saying that the Westeros of Martin's dizzily fertile imagination is no more destined for peace, calm and predictability than the Middle East of our \\"real\\" world from which it seems to take some palpable overtones. And not surprisingly, A FEAST FOR CROWS (what more symbol-laden bird is there?) captures moments of awe and transcendence that do more to whet the saga-lover's appetite than to satisfy it. But the company on the journey is another matter. Whether you love them, hate them, puzzle over them, or even grieve over them, the fighting, striving and conspiring families of Westeros and beyond are built on the flesh and bones of deeply felt human nature. The same folks who will bug you to death on the Main Street bus will thoroughly entrance you as they rule over the knights, ladies, connivers and serfs of Martin's remarkable Seven Kingdoms.    Start wherever you will (but preferably at the beginning with A GAME OF THRONES) and you can count on being taken a very willing prisoner by this highest of high fantasy achievements. Look for at least a trio, maybe even a quartet, of new adventures continuing in the illustrious line of A FEAST FOR CROWS.

B0000062GK|5.0|Joe Satriani is one of the greatest guitarists in the world, period. In fact, many would claim he is THE greatest guitarist in the world. Really? Is it possible to make such a claim? This album will take you a step closer to understanding why. <br /> <br />A New Yorker who took up guitar at age 16, Satriani has had a career spanning two decades. Over that time he has established himself as not only a technical whizz, but a versatile musician and composer. Whether it be blues, rock, classical or pop, Satch has done it. But he doesn't just thrash the cliches. His strongest point is his ever-developing individual style. Highly melodic, lyrical and harmonically diverse, his efforts, perhaps most famously on the album Surfing With the Alien, became the basis of rock guitar for the next decade. <br /> <br />But then, in 1998, came what was perhaps Satriani's coming of age. The instrumental rock album Crystal Planet was to display the result of that refinement in style &#8211; an album which not only takes you on a multifarious musical journey, but also reiks of stylistic charm. <br /> <br />Built upon a minimalistic rock base, Satriani uses elements of  modern, alterna and power-ballad rock, techno and pop to create an intensely attractive genre blend. The exact style itself is difficult to describe, combining clean distorted and overdriven guitars in an ambient reverb. One of the most palatable albums I have ever listened to, despite plunging through contrasting landscapes and aural scenery, it remains highly listenable and stylistically consistent. For me, it's Satriani's take on  commercial rock genres of the late 90s and 2000s. <br /> <br />Satriani's lead guitar is the heart and soul of this album. For the majority of the tracks, it is simply Satch, bass and drums. And yet he produces his most convincing performance yet. Why? Quite simply, it is his size. Extremely strong, cantabile melody lines are supported with hypnotic harmony and absorbing tonality &#8211; nevertoo challenging to the ear, but yet remaining connotative &#8211; build a universe of imagery surrounded by abundant atmosphere. Although there are times where two or three other guitars and the occasional keyboard nick in to hold the groove, it's never any more than simple riffs or supporting comp lines. Satriani's main guitar holds up this entire album. <br /> <br />But let's not discount the quality of the supporting musicians. Stu Hamm delivers a shining performance, with his winding bass lines not only laying a solid foundation but often playing lines which appear to consolidate a rhythm guitar. Jeff Campitelli keeps up with the wide range of feels well, in his usual creative but no-nonsense manner, while Eric Caudieux adds some sensory polish through clever synth and effect touches. <br /> <br />Despite expressing a myriad of moods, from a very upbeat opening track (Up in the Sky), past the driving groove of Raspberry Jam Delta V, to the final reflective lullaby which concludes the album, never does it become self-indulgent. There's always a new feel, a new chord progression or some new harmonies around the corner, but it remains simple and succinct enough to avoid being over the top. Satriani displays his usual mind-boggling technique, but certainly not to the point of showing off, at any stage. He simply uses his wide-reaching repetoire to broaden his expression in a controlled fashion, unafraid to refrain if necessary. <br /> <br />This album approaches on what I would term 'true pop'. Perhaps testiment to the grazioso vocalist sound Satriani manages to achieve, combined with decent pop writing, this is an album which is full of memorable melodies and catchy riffs. And yet it never becomes annoying. No matter what time of the day, what mood you might be in, it's listenable and enjoyable. What everyone wants in an album. <br /> <br />Interested in further Satriani listening? Surfing With the Alien, The Extremist and Strange Beautiful Music are his strongestall-round releases, while Engines of Creation, Satriani's techno project, is a good example of his versatility.

B000093BDX|3.0|It's hard to say anything bad about an album that contains such classic songs as, \\"California Girls,\\" \\"Don't Worry Baby,\\" and just about all of the early tracks on this disc.  However, I will.  This is yet another attempt to release a \\"Best Of\\" Beach Boys album that downgrades them into a \\"summer fun\\" band that never did anything deeper.  While containing many great tunes, I fear that many casual fans may buy this album and think that it's all of the Beach Boys catalogue they'll ever need.  Here are the reasons why that's a bad idea: <br /> <br />A.  This album contains three songs from the Pet Sounds album: \\"Wouldn't It Be Nice,\\" \\"God Only Knows,\\" and \\"Sloop John B.\\"  Pet Sounds is an absolutely essential album to own, especially if you want to get into the Beach Boys (Rolling Stone also recently named it the second best album of all time).  Don't settle for just owning the three most popular songs. <br /> <br />B.  While the mammoth follow-up to Pet Sounds, \\"Smile,\\" was scrapped and never released as a Beach Boys album (Brian Wilson finally finished it and released it himself last year), why didn't they use any of the fantastic songs from those sessions?  \\"Cabinessence,\\" the un-truncated \\"Heroes and Villains,\\" and especially that album's crowning acheivement, \\"Surf's Up,\\" are all missing in action.  These innovative, brilliantly written songs truly represent the best the Beach Boys ever got (especially with the latter song).  While not a \\"Smile\\" cut, the omission of their best 70s song, \\"'Til I Die\\" (one of Brian's personal favorites), is also confounding. <br /> <br />C.  The album contains far too many cuts from the Boys' \\"past-their-prime-nostalgia-act\\" period (i.e., anything past about 1975) when Mike Love was desperately clinging to popularity by writing surfy songs as if it was decades earlier.  This is apparent on tracks such as the cringeworthy cover of Chuck Berry's \\"Rock and Roll Music,\\" \\"Getcha Back,\\" and the horrendous, 1988 mistake, \\"Kokomo\\" (is it really even a Beach Boys song without Brian Wilson's involvement?) <br /> <br />If you need a collection of early Beach Boys hits and you can't get your hands on a copy of the wonderfully mastered, now out-of-print \\"Endless Summer,\\" buy this disc.  You won't be disappointed with those lovely, early songs.  If you really want do dig deeper into *why* the Beach Boys are regarded as one of history's finest bands, be sure to get a copy of \\"Pet Sounds\\" and download some of those key \\"Smile\\" tracks.

B000AMJG4Y|5.0|It's hard to write a review for this movie from the point of view of someone who hasn't played Final Fantasy VII for the original Playstation. Much like how people will recommend reading a book over the movie based on the book (unless you absolutely hate reading) it will be hard to understand more of the subtle tones in the movie.  Like what the story with the Turks is or why Cloud continues to think of Aeris and Zack even if the movie tries to include some of the more significant parts of the backstory.  I would recommend playing the game and then watching the movie (though PS1 graphics haven't carried over well in the new age of the XBOX 360 and other next gen systems).  Understanding that this probably won't exactly be the easiest thing for casual watchers to do, I'll write more for the non-fans since all FFVII diehards will have no problem watching this movie. <br /> <br />I'll end by saying that this is not a 5 star movie unless you have a complete grasp on the story.
