It's bigger on action and oozes a sense of style that cannot be captured with live action.  Imagine the Matrix times 10.  Sure, some of the action is a bit over the top, but it brings more of a sense of awe that people can do CG like that than it does the sense of disbelief and disdain for that kind of action. <br /> <br />In the end, I'd have to say that this movie is recommended for anyone who likes video games and/or action movies.  If you're expecting something deeper and philisophical and artsy (in the traditional sense), then you're better off passing on this and watching something else. <br />
B0007PAMR4|4.0|The extended cut isn't a big deal.  All the footage used was cutting room floor junk unfit for a theatrical print (damaged, unfinished, poorly acted, unable to be match cut, etc), which is why Lynch took his name off that one.  Technically Lynch never had the editing rights to begin with (something he'd never overlook again).  Lynch sold out.  He admitted it.  Some of the footage has never been seen since, like the scenes concerning bulb agriculture or the Arakeen palace garden...both done faithfully to the book.  The Extended TV Edition's novelty unfortunately wears off very quickly.  I've also heard the DTS mix that's been in foreign markets for a long time is nothing to write home about.  However, this will be the first time any anamorphic version of Dune has been made available in America.  Ironic that I just finally got a video card that lets me take letterbox DVD's and make them look almost exactly like anamorphic DVD's on my widescreen TV.  Funny.<br /><br />Addition:  If the above didn't sting enough, Lynch was also signed to do two sequels.  In response to the next review, no \\"remastering\\" would have been done on the original late assembly cut, since this was not the digital age of film.  But since the original negatives for all the footage still existed, yes the quality would have been better for that version on theatrical prints...with all the sound mixed and efx shots finished.  That might be what you mean.  The original negatives for that version apparently didn't survive.  Same thing happened with Lynch's original cut of Blue Velvet, though that's not such a big deal since he still cut the theatrical version as well.  All the additional footage is from the cutting room floor scraps.  Some of them may be the same shots, but they are alternate takes of the work print material from storage.<br /><br />Also, I should clarify what I meant regarding \\"selling out\\".  This was both in monies, as well as a promise (more of an emotional compensation) to allow the director full authority over Blue Velvet's cut, minus the length requirement.  Unfortunately on Dune it was too late.  As he's said, this compromised the final result.  There is almost ZERO chance David Lynch is involved on this DVD.  It's taken the poor guy years even to admit to the facts surrounding it.  For a long time he'd just say they took it from him and ruined it.  David Lynch's Dune doesn't exist.  Raffaella De Laurentiis' version is what we've got.  I'll admit the ambiguity and confusing quality of it may have been what appealed to me early on, but you can't help but want the intended cut.  I just don't want anyone to get suckered in to thinking this DVD is going to be as special as Universal is promoting it to be.  I feel 99% certain this is just the foreign version, with the daughter introducing some deleted scenes, some stills of the production, an old Lynch making-of piece, the lousy extended TV version, and the newest anamorphic transfer of the conformed negative (or maybe a new interpositive they printed from the one in storage).  So from my perspective, the anamorphic theatrical version is good news, none of the rest is.  All the bonuses will probably just get me depressed about what we've been deprived.<br /><br />More: People at Universal are in fact spreading rumors about this DVD to hype it up in time for release, possibly to increase pre-orders from vendors.  I wouldn't be surprised if that's the whole purpose behind the delay.  David Lynch has said on his website's forum he has nothing to do with this DVD.<br /><br />Oh, and I also agree the cover art up there is dorky.<br /><br />02/14/2006:<br /><br />Cover art turns out not to be so bad, though I do prefer the other versions.  Universal and Deluxe did not do any de-dusting or de-scratching in the digital domain, likely because they only had a hidef transfer to work with, rather than a 2 to 4k version that you would really need.  The sound is a tad compressed, dialog sibilants don't like to be too loud, and there is some distortion from the final mastering being too loud on the audio end.  Picture-wise, aside from the dust, scratches, and not the greatest resolution, it is quite good.  The dynamic range of the anamorphic theatrical side is excellent, with subtle color gradations.  The only defects present in my copy from Best Buy were some very minor chapter change sound quantization glitches as it switches over, which happened more frequently than most films due to the sheer abundance of chapter and scene markers...at least one per scene.<br /><br />This film is clearly a work of stylistic \\"art\\"...whether you dig the style or not.  In my opinion, this is fine art through and through.  In an era where I can never get over the office-chair fakery of CGI, Dune's look continues to impress me.  No other film ever made will look like this again.  The photography, the set design, the casting, the sound design & music (practically the same thing in a Lynch film), the costumes, the stunningly realistic make-up...the composition in color, design, geometry, and attention to detail in each shot is something unique.  Lynch is first a painter, and it shows here perhaps more than on any other film...and probably more his personal style.  How many years has he been painting Bob the demon on his roof using toxic \\"texturing\\" materials?  Dune is further into the mind of Lynch than we'll ever get in terms of aesthetics, which is maybe why its box office failure was so tormenting for him.  There have been many great films throughout the years that flopped, though.  And Dune, based on one of the most complicated novels ever written, went up against The Terminator and 2010 that year.  A great year for science fiction, you have to admit, but likely the primary factor at work.  Terminator was quite a new experience for moviegoers with an action/chase sci-fi take, and 2010 was a far more accessible and less \\"arty\\" film than 2001.  Audiences were being spoiled with easily accessible, easily understood sci-fi in 1984.  It's no wonder Dune was such a hard sell.  If they'd simply held off another year on the release it might have made double.<br /><br />Besides the lack of certain scenes early on such as the Mapes & the knife or the palace garden scene, the primary influence of Raffaella seems to be after about the 1hr 37min mark.  It is beyond this point where the film seems heavily abridged compared to the earliest cut that Dino would have viewed.  Prior to this point the narrative flows quite nicely, even with the aforementioned omissions.  There is a great deal simply missing in the last 30% that he obviously shot but the producer felt could be left out to more quickly reach the climax.  I'm not saying everything belongs in the film.  Many of the deleted shots/scenes simply feel too bookish and explanative...too overt of an attempt to inform us rather than develop character and story.  The extended version's acting is generally overdone, while the theatrical release is appropriate and rousing.  I'm quite fond of Lynch's direction here and the choice in takes used in terms of acting honesty.  But the final scene lacks the impact it clearly would have had with more development of Paul and his mother amongst the Fremen, the battles, and, of course, Paul and Chauni's love...growing.  You can't just say that.  You've got to show it through scenes of substance.  A montage of battle and sex doesn't cut it, and it leads right into the abrupt taking of the Water of Life.  The montage should have been separate scenes.  I don't have a problem with the revised Water of Life concept.  It simply needed more of the Jihad and terrible purpose dreams.  With that, the earlier scene cursing his mother, more scenes of romance and battle, Thufir's death, and the announcement of marrying Irulan, I think the film would have been improved.  I think Thufir's death is a quality scene.  Add the garden scene, the doctor taking the bag to the thopter near burningpalm trees, and do a CG scene of the desert blooming then quickly dying, and I think the film would pretty much be complete.  Still no proper sword/shield fighting, but...<br /><br />As far as the weirding modules, if you've read my \\"So You Want To Read Dune For The First Time\\" guide, or my book and letterboxed movie reviews, then you know what my grasp of the Dune universe is. Case in point: the calendar in Dune is recorded since the creation of the Spacing Guild.  The events in the book take place more than 24,000 years from now.  The initial colonizations occured with sub-light generational starships millenia before...essentially a pre-history.  Remember, they had to discover Arrakus through conventional means long before the spice could ever be used for folding space.  Thus the Fremen really are no less natives than Native Americans.  In spite of how different it is from the book, watching this film again after all these years I must admit Lynch's interpretation is inspired.  I don't mean that in the sense of that's how I'd do it...I wouldn't.  Mine would be uncompromising.  But the concept of the modules and how it integrates so well with the precepts of Dune is obviously inspired...from on high, from Lynch's unconsciousness, from someone else's, or maybe 'cause a little birdie told him.  Who knows...  But you don't just contrive an idea like that off the top of your head for the hell of it because you're lazy or feel like screwing up a masterpiece.  It loses the nuance of what the weirding way meant in Herbert's book, but succeeds with a more blatant, and I think ultimately successful take for this film.  In a sense, the modules are a physicality of human thought and potential, exemplified by Paul's weirding-derived telekinesis at the end.  Whether I would have done it or not doesn't change the fact that there's evidence of an inspired idea in it.  Then you must consider how the film ended up a little butchered before reaching theaters.  I think this will be the best version we will ever get.  One can hope enough people will buy it to convince Universal to do a 4k transfer of the conformed negative and attempt an ultimate edition, free of dust, scratches, or slightly compressed audio.  I'm quite satisfied with this release, though.nder Dune was such a hard sell.  If they'd simply held off another year on the release it might have made double.    Besides the lack of certain scenes early on such as the Mapes & the knife or the palace garden scene, the primary influence of Raffaella seems to be after about the 1hr 37min mark.  It is beyond this point where the film seems heavily abridged compared to the earliest cut that Dino would have viewed.  Prior to this point the narrative flows quite nicely, even with the aforementioned omissions.  There is a great deal simply missing in the last 30% that he obviously shot but the producer felt could be left out to more quickly reach the climax.  I'm not saying everything belongs in the film.  Many of the deleted shots/scenes simply feel too bookish and explanative...too overt of an attempt to inform us rather than develop character and story.  The extended version's acting is generally overdone, while the theatrical release is appropriate and rousing.  I'm quite fond of Lynch's direction here and the choice in takes used in terms of acting honesty.  But the final scene lacks the impact it clearly would have had with more development of Paul and his mother amongst the Fremen, the battles, and, of course, Paul and Chauni's love...growing.  You can't just say that.  You've got to show it through scenes of substance.  A montage of battle and sex doesn't cut it, and it leads right into the abrupt taking of the Water of Life.  The montage should have been separate scenes.  I don't have a problem with the revised Water of Life concept.  It simply needed more of the Jihad and terrible purpose dreams.  With that, the earlier scene cursing his mother, more scenes of romance and battle, Thufir's death, and the announcement of marrying Irulan, I think the film would have been improved.  I think Thufir's death is a quality scene.  Add the garden scene, the doctor taking the bag to the thopter near burning palm trees, and do a CG scene of the desert blooming then quickly dying, and I think the film would pretty much be complete.  Still no proper sword/shield fighting, but...    As far as the weirding modules, if you've read my \\"So You Want To Read Dune For The First Time\\" guide, or my book and letterboxed movie reviews, then you know what my grasp of the Dune universe is. Case in point: the calendar in Dune is recorded since the creation of the Spacing Guild.  The events in the book take place more than 24,000 years from now.  The initial colonizations occured with sub-light generational starships millenia before...essentially a pre-history.  Remember, they had to discover Arrakus through conventional means long before the spice could ever be used for folding space.  Thus the Fremen really are no less natives than Native Americans.  In spite of how different it is from the book, watching this film again after all these years I must admit Lynch's interpretation is inspired.  I don't mean that in the sense of that's how I'd do it...I wouldn't.  Mine would be uncompromising.  But the concept of the modules and how it integrates so well with the precepts of Dune is obviously inspired...from on high, from Lynch's unconsciousness, from someone else's, or maybe 'cause a little birdie told him.  Who knows...  But you don't just contrive an idea like that off the top of your head for the hell of it because you're lazy or feel like screwing up a masterpiece.  It loses the nuance of what the weirding way meant in Herbert's book, but succeeds with a more blatant, and I think ultimately successful take for this film.  In a sense, the modules are a physicality of human thought and potential, exemplified by Paul's weirding-derived telekinesis at the end.  Whether I would have done it or not doesn't change the fact that there's evidence of an inspired idea in it.  Then you must consider how the film ended up a little butchered before reaching theaters.  I think this will be the best version we will ever get.  One can hope enough people will buyit to convince Universal to do a 4k transfer of the conformed negative and attempt an ultimate edition, free of dust, scratches, or slightly compressed audio.  I'm quite satisfied with this release, though.

Crimson had already become famous and sere appearing in America before this album was even in conception. <br />That is all.

B000BEZQ0Y|4.0|Just as the new film of \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" stands in stark contrast to all previous adaptations, so does its score break away from the mold of all previous Austen-adaptation scores. Oh, yes, there's the familiar trilling piano we've grown to expect, but this score is more along the lines of a Merchant-Ivory film; aching, moody, and transcendent.<br /><br />Written by Dario Marianelli and performed by pianist Jean-Yves Thibaudet, the brief score only clocks in at forty-two minutes and twenty-two seconds, but that is plenty of time for some great music. From haunting violin work (\\"A Postcard from Henry Purcell\\") to the beautiful theme for Lizzy herself (\\"Liz on Top of the World\\"), the music is rich and varied. \\"Arrival at Netherfield\\" has a jittery sense of excitement, and all the tracks composed for the dances in the film (\\"Meryton Townhall\\" and \\"Another Dance\\") are lively and joyous, as is \\"Can't Slow Down\\".  \\"Your Hands Are Cold\\" is the true standout, however; sweeping, beautiful, and, like the scene it was written for, unforgettable.<br /><br />The only element I think lacking is a stronger main theme for Darcy himself, which would have been nice. Really, other than that, I can find no fault with Marianelli's work. If you are a fan of the new film (or a writer looking for background music), this is a must-have.<br /><br />GRADE: B+

0553801503|2.0|Feast for Crows is sadly becoming increasingly typical in the genre fiction I read.  It is driven by plot twists that grow increasingly convoluted until you begin to realize that the author truly has no idea how to resolve all the tangles and knots. <br /> <br />I have never seen a book so full of editorialized excuses.  On Mr. Martin's web site, in a note/aftermath at the end of Feast, even in the acknowledgements.  He *knows* this is a subpar effort and only just stops shy of apologizing for it. <br /> <br />It is quite the post-modern experience to be reading a fantasy novel and thinking through it all, \\"The author can't manage this.\\"  I honestly don't believe the man is capable of finishing the series, and, at least to my mind, thereby joins the august company of Robert Jordan's Freudian nightmare - The Wheel of Time. <br /> <br />Martin points optimistically towards the release of the next book in 2006.  Already in these reviews we see that date slipping to 2007.  Or will it in fact be another 3-5 years?  Given the delayed release of Feast, and the disappointment attendant to that release, you'd have to be quite the optimist... the kind of person who would be quickly humiliated and dishonored in Martin's universe. <br /> <br />To be specific - the characterization is as spot on as it has always been.  Martin has had this gift from the beginning of the series and there's no point denying it to him now.  Some complain about the pacing, but personally I don't object to spending time with the characters. <br /> <br />The plotting and overall structure of the book, though, is pretty inexcusable.  I don't want to spoil (and won't) but Martin claims to have split one book into two in order to follow the full story arcs of half the characters, instead of half the story arc for all the characters.  But in Feast, I don't see where he completed the story arc for *any* characters short of the ones who die... and there really aren't that many of them in comparison to previous books. <br /> <br />He leaves us with serial cliffhangers more suitable to soap opera than to quality fiction, and the knowledge that the characters' problems cannot possibly resolved in the next book (because we know in advance that they won't be in it).  So we will get more teasers 2 books from now.  Given Martin's recent output, that could well take a decade. <br /> <br />I'm terribly disappointed in Feast for Crows.  It's a great place in the series to take a stand and say - no more.  Maybe I'll pick up the remaining books when he's finished the whole series.  I really don't believe he ever will.

0385510454|3.0|As a reward for having one of my book signings at a first class book store in Durham N.C., I got to pick this book as a free gift from the store. I really wanted to read a Grisham thriller. But this is not one.            The slow plot was not a realistic senario that I could believe---Having worked in the Federal Government, I never felt that this story could really happen. Moreover, I agree with the many other people in their Amazon reviews who have mentioned that the author put too much Italian food and travel guide material as filler for this thriller.          However the obvious key mistakes of how Washington works made me write this review. For example, the main person who solves the hero Joel Backman's \\"life or death\\" problem is, according to Grisham, \\"Major Wes Roland... the Head guy\\" of the Defense Intelligence Agency(DIA)----Grisham goes on to tell the reader that Roland has run the DIA for \\"ten, maybe twelve years\\". This is clearly wrong and the author...or his editors should have checked with someone in Washington. DIA, a major Dept of Defense agency, is almost always commanded by a three star General or a Vice Admiral (NEVER a MAJOR). Not to belabor the point, but any career military officer will tell you that a major would NEVER run any world-wide intelligence organization with over 7000 employees (in my view, that number is a sensitive fact unfortunately too easily available on the internet). In addition, any Washington insider knows that DIA directors' tours of command rarely exceed three years.          With major mistakes flawing the too-quick ending and the unrealistic plot, I was one disappointed reader.         In the future, if the climax and answer to your book plot is in Washington, please come to DC, Mr. G, spend a few days talking to some smart people who know how this place really works.           Mr G, I like what I know about you and how you write with a good plot behind you. However this plot is sub-Grisham, so you earn only three stars this time from me (a notorious easy grader!).

A feeling of hope spread through the crowd as Green Day performed their songs.  The entire concert was a rollercoaster of emotion; however, it left everyone anticipating what would come next. <br /> Jimmy Eat World opened the concert with upbeat, well known songs.  The crowd was still filing in during Jimmy Eat World's entire set.  Everyone knew that Green Day would soon be on stage.  Green Day is a California based band that has been together for sixteen years.  The lead singer is Billie Joe Armstrong, the bass player is Mike Dirnt, and Tr Cool plays the drums.  By the time Green Day was about to begin the Palace of Auburn Hills was packed with energetic fans.  The concert was sold-out, and 16,000 people were waiting for the arrival of the band.  The atmosphere was teeming with expectation, and then a pink, beer drinking bunny came on stage.  It was hilarious because the bunny really got the crowd into a laid back spirit.  Then out of nowhere the \\"YMCA\\" song came over the speakers, and everyone began dancing along with the bunny.  The pink bunny entertained the crowd and was a pleasant surprise, leaving the audience with no clue as to what would come next.  Many concerts that are too predictable can be boring or tiresome, however, quite the opposite was true with the Green Day concert.  When Green Day came on stage, the crowd was already extremely pumped up, and it seemed as if the band could tell.  Before any songs were even played, Billie Joe got the entire building to do the wave. The wave resulted in every person in the building on their feet screaming for music.  They opened with songs from their new album, including, \\"American Idiot,\\" \\"St. Jimmy,\\" \\"Holiday,\\"and \\"Jesus of Suburbia.\\"  The new album is called American Idiot, and the album won a Grammy for Best Rock Album of 2005.  When Green Day played the first note of \\"American Idiot,\\" the speakers began to vibrate.  There were speakers everywhere, from the floor to the ceiling blaring music.  The sound quality of the band's instruments and the singing of the lyrics was also spectacular.  Many times when a concert is enclosed in a building, it is very hard to hear the words over the bands instruments, but every word of Green Day's songs was heard loud and clear, throughout the entire building.  It seemed as if every person knew all the words to each song and gladly sang along with the band.  American Idiot is an album with a theme behind the lyrics, and the concert took on that theme as well.  During the Green Day concert, Billie Joe made many comments about his dislike for George W. Bush.  He went on to explain that he did not want to force his beliefs on the audience, but he wanted everyone to find something they believed in and fight for it.  Billie Joe's remarks never seemed to offend the crowd; in fact the opposite was true.  When the audience was told to fight for what they believed in, there was a surge of excitement as everyone yelled in agreement.   <br /> As the concert progressed, the fans grew louder and louder, their enthusiasm growing with each song.  Green Day has eight smash albums and they included songs from a variety of them including, \\"Longview,\\" \\"Hitichin A Ride,\\" \\"2000 Light Years Away,\\" and \\"Brain Stew.\\"  In between each song Billie Joe would scream to the crowd to make sure they were still with him, and of course every face was eagerly watching every move the band made.  Not only was the band interesting to watch, but the special effects were enormous.  Green Day included things in their concert that were very original and electrifying.  During the high points in their songs fire works would shoot from the top of their stage, or during the finalnote of a song flames would erupt behind the band.  The music was energizing, and the special effects were stimulating.  After they had played a number of their smash hits, the band decided to bring people on stage that could play instruments.  A guitarist, a drummer, and a bass player were picked from the crowd and quickly taught the song.  Then the crowd watched as a new band was put together in a matter of seconds.  It was a refreshing twist to see that Green Day was comfortable enough to let members of the audience on stage for that once in a life time opportunity.  Those three people were beaming when the song was over.   <br /> All of the songs played at the concert were very exciting but none could compare to the last song.  Green Day acknowledged that it was September 11th, and gave a special tribute to all those who had suffered in New York City.  Billie Joe asked everyone to hold up their lighters or cell phone and sing along to \\"Wake Me Up When September Ends.\\"  Hearing the moving lyrics and looking at the hundreds of lights was extremely emotional.  At this point in the concert it was not about the band anymore, it had become more than that.  Everyone was at the Palace in honor of the heroes, and in memory of those who died just four short years ago. Green Day exited the stage to a thunderous roar from the audience, but of course there was an encore.  The encore consisted of popular songs like \\"Maria,\\" \\"Boulevard of Broken Dreams,\\" and \\"Time of your Life (Good Riddance),\\" but also included was the song \\"We are the Champions.\\"  Everyone knows that song and if someone didn't, the words were illuminated on a giant screen.  It was a unique way to keep the crowd involved after an amazing two hour show.   <br /> Green Day does not consist of one singer, or one guitar player, they are a talented group of men who put a band together sixteen years ago.  Sixteen years is an eternity to some people, and during that time most people lose friends while picking up newones.  This concert revealed the bond these men share because their music is heart felt, and they work amazingly well together.  If there is ever an opportunity to attend a Green Day concert then go because this concert proved that Green Day knows how to entertain and rock a crowd. <br /> <br />

B0000AQS0F|5.0|I had never heard of this series. I ordered the DVD set on a lark. I have always like Science Fiction and have looked for film/video adaptations. I have usually been disappointed but I keep trying. Finding a gem like this one makes the effort worth while. <br /> <br />The basic premise is of the crew of a tramp freighter who make their way by carrying freights, the occasional smuggling job and a few other less than legal operation. These are invariably conducted against people who deserve to have been on the losing side. The captain and first mate are old war buddies. They were both on the losing side of a civil war. The mate is married to the ships pilot. The ship's engineer is a sweet, somewhat nave and technically competent young lady. A tough, mercenary type rounds out the regular crew.  <br /> <br />In the first episode, they take on a series of passengers. One of them is a \\"shepherd\\", which is a sort of itinerant Christian priest. He has a mysterious past we never really learn about. A brother and sister also come on board. The brother is a highly skilled surgeon and the sister is a genius who had secret experiments run on her by government agents. They are on the run from the same government agents. The other \\"permanent\\" passenger is a courtesan. She leases one of the ship's shuttles as her place of business. While the crew is doing their thing, she does hers. <br /> <br />Much of this series seems like a cowboy picture, right down to the horses, saloons and brothels. In a strange way, it works well in the context of the series. It is well done. I am very sorry that the series was cancelled because it is very good. <br /> <br />Synopses of the episodes appear below: <br /> <br /> <br />Serenity - the crew of the Serenity agrees to pick up a less than legal cargo but gets stiffed on their fee when they try to deliver it. Unless they can find somewhere to sell it, they won't have the cash for parts, fuel, salary or anything else. So they try to less it on someborder areas. To help pay the way, they take on some passengers also. One of the passengers turns out to be smuggling a fugitive and another is a federal agent sent to bring in everyone. I get the impression that the government types are not very nice. When you throw in a courtesan, some cannibals and a preacher, things get interesting. <br /> <br />The Train Job - This one seems more like a western but doesn't suffer from that. The crew is hired to rob a train on a frontier planet. The goods they are hired to purloin belong to the Federation government so no one really minds or things it is \\"wrong\\". They also enjoy doing the job right under the noses of Federation troops. The crew doesn't really know what they are stealing. It is only when the train gets to it destination that they learn that they have stolen desperately needed medical supplies. The leads the crew to try to return the goods without getting caught by the feds or the crime boss they were doing job for. This is to be done while the crew is still be pursued by the secret government agency from whom one of the passengers escaped. It's a good and exciting episode. <br /> <br />Bushwhacked - While doing nothing in particular, the crew of the Serenity encounter a derelict floating in space. When they go aboard, they find that the crew has been slaughtered by the Reevers (cannibal lunatics) mentioned in the first episode. They left one survivor and a valuable cargo. The crew attempts to help the survivor and salvage the cargo but their efforts are interrupted by a Federation ship. The captain of that ship assumes that it is the crew of the Serenity who committed the atrocities. The crew have to protect themselves, establish their innocence and hide the fugitives who have become passengers. <br /> <br />Shindig - The crew returns to the planet Persephone, where the series started. They are looking for business opportunities as usual and a possibility pops up. The captain sees an opportunity for a smugglingrun and goes to make contact at a fancy party hosted by the local gentry. To keep this episode interesting, Innarra, the staff courtesan has a date with a local bigwig. He and the captain have a bit of a tiff and wind up in a duel...with swords. There is not a lot of call for swords on spaceships.  <br /> <br />Safe - In seems that nothing can go right. The crew of the Serenity make planetfall with the consignment of cattle they picked up in the last episode and are about to collect their payment. Then things go wrong as they inevitably must. The local law shows up to arrest the cattle buyers just as the money is changing hands and the crew get involved in the shootout. They help out the law but the parson gets himself shot...very seriously shot. The only two missing from the scene are the two fugitives who have wandered off. The captain thinks they might get in the way of the deal making but now the doctor's services are needed. Unfortunately, he and his sister have gotten themselves kidnapped by some religious types who live in the hills. They are glad to have the doctor but they think the sister is a witch and must burn. Saving the preacher and rescuing the siblings proves to be a sticky situation. <br /> <br />Our Mrs. Reynolds - Somehow, we don't really know how, the crew of the Serenity find themselves helping a rural community defend themselves from bandits. After the big celebration, the crew get back on board take of and find that they have an extra passenger. It seems that, according to the local customs, the captain has gotten himself married. That is news to everyone. The young girl is seemingly nave but she is not what she seems. Someone wants the Serenity for scrap.  <br /> <br />Jaynestown - Jayne Cobb is perhaps the least likeable member of the Serenity crew. He is selfish, not too bright and always ready to fight. He has a long history of leaving planets behind while being on the run. In this episode, the crew sets down to pick up an illicit cargoand Jayne is worried because he knows he left the place on the run. He adopts a disguise. Much to everyone's surprise, everyone learns that Jayne Cobb has become a folk hero to the people on the planet complete with a statue in the public square. All of this came about because of a misunderstanding. He never intended to help those people; he did it by accident but he is still a hero. Heroes have people who don't like them and on this planet that include the local magistrate. <br /> <br />Out of Gas - Most series wait until at least the second season before having a retrospective episode. This one takes place halfway through the first season but it has a difference. Instead of recycling footage from old episodes this one has all new footage. The situation involves a serious mechanical failure while the ship is in transit. Life support is failing and the captain sends his crew off in the two shuttles while he stays aboard to try and fix things. While this is going on, we are treated to flashback showing how the crew came to be assembled. <br /> <br />Ariel - When the mysterious female passenger with mental problems starts getting worse, her brother the doctor comes up with a seemingly simple scheme to serve everyone's needs. The crew is to help the doc smuggle sis into a hospital for some tests and the doc agrees to help them steal some high dollar drugs to sell on the fringe planets. These are not recreational pharmaceuticals but vital medicines in short supply. The plan seems to work smoothly until treachery becomes apparent. <br /> <br />War Stories - In the second episode, the crew is hired to pull a train heist. They pull it off but, when all is said and done, they find that they don't want to keep the goods. The natives need the stolen medications more than the crew needs the money. This is all good and noble and such but it hacks of the crime boss who put them up to it. The crew returned the money but the boss wants revenge. In this episode, he manages to capture the captain and the pilot. It is up to the rest of the crew to get them out.  <br /> <br />Trash - A few episodes back, the captain got himself accidentally married. The blushing bride turned out to be a con woman and they only barely got away with their lives and their ship. This time, at a Smuggler rendezvous, the captain runs into an old war buddy who happens to have gotten himself married to the same piece of trash. When the story comes out, the wife gets stranded. Captain Mal is about to strand her as well but she manages to talk him into one of her schemes. Naturally, the \\"lady\\" has an angle of her own. Make that lots of angles...and curves...and treachery. The crew has a few ideas of their own but nothing is going to go as planned. <br /> <br />The Message - When the crew stops at a station for a mail call, they get a surprise. A corpse has been mailed to the captain and Zo. The corpse turns out to be an old war buddy. His last request is that the Serenity take him home for burial. Things are not as they seem, however. The corpse is not dead. Instead, he is smuggling body parts and there are other who want the parts, without the rest of the body. As everyone turns on everyone else over conflicting loyalties, the situation gets tense.  <br /> <br />Heart of Gold - When Inarra, the courtesan, gets a distress call, she talks the crew of Serenity into helping an old friend of hers who is the madam of a bordello on a backwater planet. A local powerbroker with a barren wife want to sire an heir on one of the house girls. He manages to plant his crop and intends to claim it by force. The crew intend to prevent that. And a good time is had by most. <br /> <br />Objects in Space - River, the female fugitive, continues to get more and more erratic. This troubles the crew who fear not only for themselves but for her as well. Things are not helped in that there is a very large reward for her capture. This tends to promote suspicion with many of the people with whichthey deal. In this episode, a bounty hunter manages to sneak aboard and waylay the crew one by one. River, though, is not without her own methods. <br />
B000B8QEZG|5.0|The Queen of Pop returns to the disco inferno<br /><br />Back in 1983, when Madonna first burst on the scene, she resurrected dance music which had suffered a decline following its height of popularity in the 70s. The master of reinvention, Madonna has since went on to explore other styles and has displayed deeper meanings in her music. She still knows the value of her roots, however,  and \\"Confessions on a Dance Floor\\" throws aside the spirituality, the Kabalistic karma, etc. for an unabashed dance album. This cd is pure fun, one to crank up and drive by and to put it on at a party and let it play. There are no silent pauses between songs - every song fuses into the next effortlessly.<br /><br />Madonna actually digs deeper into the disco era with many of the songs reminiscent of music from the 70s, before she hit the scene. \\"Hung Up,\\" the first single, samples Abba's \\"Gimme, Gimme, Gimme\\" and you can catch homage's to the S.O.S. Band in \\"Get Together\\" and \\"Future Lovers\\" certainly has a Donna Summer \\"I Feel Love\\" type of beat. But make no mistake, these are no copycat songs. The only direct sampling here is from Abba - everything else is a unique blend of  throbbing multi-layered tempos and psychedelic overtures.  Every track is \\"catchy\\" but stand-outs include the hypnotic \\"Forbidden Love,\\" \\"Sorry\\" (rumored to be the second single release) and I don't see how anyone could sit still for \\"Jump.\\"

Namely, How Kind of You and Anyway.  <br /> <br />How Kind of You is slow and hypnotic, and if Coldplay had recorded a cover of this song, I doubt I would ever suspect they didn't write it, unless I'd heard Paul's original first.  <br /> <br />Anyway is marred by a tacked-on bunch of studio garbage that runs on for three minutes at the end. In his Rolling Stone interview McCartney said that when he tries to do angry or emotionally dark music, he usually gets it all wrong. But this time he got it right.  <br /> <br />This Never Happened Before is the sort of shmaltz that Paul gets so much grief about, but shmaltz doesn't get any better than this.  <br /> <br />Producer Nigel Godrich really did make a difference, I think, wrenching the best he could from McCartney. Unfortunately, the juices just aren't flowing like they were in the 1970s, so the other tunes are listenable but not exceptional.  <br /> <br />It's great to hear Paul at the top of his game again, but it's hit and miss. I just think it could have been A LOT better. <br /> <br />Packaging: 4/5 <br />I would have preferred the set to come in a typical DVD sized case as opposed to a double CD album case. Personal preference, but I think it would look better on my DVD shelf like that. The packaging is nice though. I really like the clear sleeve encasing the cardboard album packaging. The interior packaging? We'll just say it fits with the title. <br /> <br />CD: 5/5 <br />The live album is exactly what one would expect from a live recording. I really don't have much to say except that of everything in this set, it was the only thing I didn't have a complaint about. <br /> <br />DVD: 3/5 <br />I'll start off with the bonus features - a photo gallery. Had some very lovely photos set to the instrumentals for Boulevard of Broken Dreams. All in all, rather boring. You couldn't navigate and it spent what felt like ages on each image. <br /> <br />The DVD itself. The editing was excellent. There were some real creative touches with camera angles that looked like they were lifted from an old television, overhead shots, every angle you could imagine in a widescreen format. Probably the smallest of my problems with the DVD was that the documentary was interlaced between each track so you'd get a song then some behind the scenes and interview footage. The documentary was excellent. It just should have been a bonus feature and not part of the concert. The way it is was rather jarring. <br /> <br />The show was excellent. Just not the best one to showcase the tour, to immortalise on DVD. At least not as the only release. There's many reasons for this, and I will go into all of them. First off, it was filmed at the National Bowl in Milton Keynes. For those unfamiliar with the locale, it is in England. I think it is a great locale for filming - plenty of space for the cameras, thus giving the ability to film a large crowd and have wide, sweeping shots of the stage and audience. The National Bowl has a capacity of around 100,000 spectators. The crowd Green Day performed for the day this was filmed? 65,000. Leaving a lot of open space that was visible and stood out in the wide, sweeping shots of the stage and audience. <br /> <br />Continuing with filming location, by choosing somewhere outside America, you're creating a COMPLETELY different emotional atmosphere for the show. American Idiot is a very highly charged album which reflects the post 9/11 political environment here in the United States. Not that Brits don't understand, because the US is obviously not the only place to have been affected by 9/11 or other terrorist attacks, it just isn't the same. Choosing to put out this UK performance rather than a US performance made the DVD more reminiscent of seeing them in 2002 on the Pop Disaster Tour rather than in 2005 on the American Idiot Tour. <br /> <br />I've listened to the live recording from Leeds from 2004. Excellent recording. Excellent show. I enjoyed it. I saw the AOL Live Webcast of ther show back in September or October. Excellent show, and I could feel the political tension in it. I couldn't quite feel it in this DVD. I saw them live this tour on September 11th. Four years after the attacks. I think of all the shows to be filmed for DVD, to really capture the essence of the American Idiot Tour, it should have been that show. Not because I was there, but because of how charged the atmosphere was. I don't think I need to explain any further on that reasoning. <br /> <br />I also believe that an indoor arena show woul have been better than an outdoor show. A lot of the lighting effects early on in the show were lot to the fact that it was still light outside. The audience wasn't as tightly packed. While I love that there was a crowd of 65,000 - it wasn't a sold out show. While an arena show might only have fit 18,000-22,000 it would have been a tightly packed 18,000-22,000. The show's lighting and pyrotechnics would not have been lost to the daylight. <br /> <br />But for everything that I thought could have been better, I still found the DVD an excellent purchase and enjoyable diversion.

B00080ZG10|3.0|The master of the small movie apparently wants to be the master of the epic film. Unfortunately this is a tall order for anyone, especially for someone who hasn't made a particularly good film (small or epic) since 1990. But at least this time he is trying for a masterpiece and not just pissing away his time with garbage. There will be inevitable comparisons with \\"Citizen Kane\\" (in fact at one point in the film a reference is even made to W.R. Hearst) but anyone who does so should get a reality check. A more appropriate side-by-side comparison would be Tim Burton's \\"Ed Wood\\", and this is a comparison that \\"Aviator\\" loses.    Which is not to say that \\"Aviator\\" is a bad movie, although certainly it is bad history and in need of major trimming. It is generally entertaining fared much better at the box office than expected.     There are a number of flying scenes and two are very good, the night landing on a golf course and the take-off of the Spruce Goose. There are also two that are very weak. The worst is the setting of a new speed record which has a serious continuity error, the plane on the runway was clearly not the plane in the error (bad pun intended). This was so obvious (one had a partial canopy and one had a full canopy) and they cut back and forth so much that I wondered if I was hallucinating the disparity-hard to believe that it was not handled better. The other was the crash of the spy plane in a Hollywood neighborhood. The cartoonish shots of various homeowners watching their houses being destroyed from the inside would fit a Cohn Brothers comedy but are totally out of place in this film.    The film has one great performance, Cate Blanchette channels the vocal patterns and mannerisms of Katherine Hepburn, her scenes are the highlights of the film and fortunately she has a lot of scenes. It took a lot of courage for Scorsese to not just structure the film around someone as familiar as Hepburn but to have her character played in a manner where she was recognizable to her fans.    Alan Alda does great as a slimy senator. Adam Baldwin is slick as the strangely likable Pan Am President. Josie Moran, Kelli Garner and the other Kate (Beckinsale) are dazzling decoration, and Ian Holm provides comic relief. Apparently Scorsese felt he needed this high caliber ensemble to compensate for miscasting the lead.    And miscast he is; from DiCaprio's first line you know that this will be a painful experience; although perhaps not quite as horrible as you would expect from his prior work. Since Scorsese's break with De Niro after Cape Fear, both director and actor have suffered. You have to believe that the replacement DiCaprio takes direction well and that Scorsese is gambling that he can hit a home run with a weak actor and not have to share the credit for his triumph. But his strategy does not work as their screen version of Hughes utterly fails to capture any of the personal magnetism of their subject. I left the theatre thinking how well Titanic Leo executed the role, for his attempt was clearly earnest; but that almost any real actor could have brought nuances to the part well beyond the scope of DiCaprio's abilities-even under Scorsese's direction. The weakness of his portrayal is not as obvious when he is the only one in a scene but it takes on varying degrees of glaring when he is paired with one of the better members of the supporting cast.    I kept coming back to Johnny Depp's portrayal of Ed Wood and wishing it was he who was playing Hughes. In real life Wood was a strange guy but almost one-dimensional when compared to Hughes. But if your only exposure to them was these movie biographies you would think that Wood was far more intriguing.     Then again, what do I know?  I'm only a child.

Always ahead of his time, Philip K. Dick paints a strange tale set in a dark world for us. In comparison with the movie (just incase you saw the movie and that's what's attracting you to the book), the book is much more detailed as far as philosophical and political elements go.<br /><br />With everyone having the strange ability to influence their own emotions at the touch of a button (literally an emotion emitter), issues of free will and individual/societal values comes into play. Religious implications and undertones are present throughout the novel as well (in fact in that regard there is a major plot device which offers religion some degree of input in this apocalyptic world - Mercerism).<br /><br />I don't want to give a detailed report of the book only because I think you (the reader) should go out and experience the pleasure of unlocking this gem for your self. 0380789035|4.0|Unconventional as most of Gaiman's work, though it might not appeal to everyone! This modern day fantasy tale tells the story of a man named Shadow who was recently let out of jail - he goes through a hell of a lot of badness as soon as he's released and... well, after years of waiting to be released... he essentially has absolutely nothing left to live for.<br /><br />The story is basically about Shadow's life after he leaves prison. The tale, however, is not as simple as that (if that was simple given the fact that Shadow still needs to fill in the rest of his life with something), Shadow comes across unlikely characters along the way. Without giving too much away, expect the strange!<br /><br />Various cultures' mythologies play some role in American Gods; Shadow literally becomes a shadow of this world and enters a new world where epic-level events are occurring. Thankfully this isn't a fantasy novel in the traditional sense; Gaiman does well to keep Shadow's character in tact. He isn't \\"all for\\" the \\"fantasy\\" aspects of the story as they come to pass, in fact Shadow just lets it all flow over him... afraid to embrace the strange realities he's being forced to confront.<br /><br />A story about adapting and adjusting to life's turns (well, in a very extreme way in this case), American Gods is a fun read for anyone who has an interest in the main story and a secondary interest in either sci-fi or fantasy works (this book is not a high fantasy novel as traditional high fantasy works are concerned).<br /><br />Gaiman's masterpiece is so because not only has he transcended his own high-fantasy only writing style (he has written more serious works in the past but they are few compared to his ultra-fantasy writings), but he also provides us with an entertaining ride which is strangely believable!<br /><br />I really wish there was a way to give this book a 4.5... the only major turn off I could think of was that the ending was kind of dragged out. I'm not a big fan of Gaiman endings (with the exception of The Sandman series), but this ending just might come across as silly and poorly executed to some readers.<br /><br />Again though, all and all this was a 5 out of 5 book and worth the buy!!!big fan of Gaiman endings (with the exception of The Sandman series), but this ending just might come across as silly and poorly executed to some readers. <br /> <br />Again though, all and all this was a 5 out of 5 book and worth the buy!!!
B00000253N|5.0|There was once a time when I looked down on Bob Dylan's music and riduculed him as a talentless musician.  One album single-handedly swayed my opinion and forced me to realize his remarkable brilliance.  That album is Blood on the Tracks.  It is quite possibly the most perfect album I have ever heard, and if there has ever been a better album lyrically made, I haven't heard it.  The personal turmoil that Dylan was going through when he made BotT has been well documented, but it still fails to prepare the listener for the absolutely heart-wrenching personal struggle that he lays bare over the course of ten tracks.  Every song demands to be heard again and again, and I myself couldn't resist those demands.  The musical arrangements are often minimal and simplistic, but his pain and his genius ring as loud as any heavy metal out there.  Bob Dylan had gems before BotT and he's had some since, but for me this is his finest hour.  I couldn't imagine my music collection without it, and frankly I don't want to.

B000000W5P|5.0|By 1978, the Stones were so immersed in drugs and internal turmoil that they had every excuse to make a lousy record.  Instead, they made Some Girls.  How they managed to pull it off I'll never know, but it's one of their very best.  In addition to hammering out their trademark, gritty sound, the boys take their shots at the rising arenas of punk and disco with memorable results.  Miss You and Beast of Burden are the tracks that everyone knows from SG, but the inspired filler in between is golden.  Check out the country twang of Far Away Eyes, the out-of-control wall of noise that is Respectable and Lies, and the immaculate cover of the Temptation's Just My Imagination and you'll be smiling for days.  They've had some high points since then, but in many ways Some Girls marked the zenith of the Stones' long career. After this, they were never as fun or relevant again.

I am saddened that people want to give one star because they just hate an artist and five stars to brag about how wonderful their artist is instead of focusing on a review, but it happens here at Amazon.com all the time.)  I've  listened to Confessions on a Dance Floor three times, and I just can't get into it.  I like Stuart Price's work as Les Rythmes Digitales and with Zoot Woman, but I was underwhelmed with his  production on this album.  I appreciate the fact that Price thought of the idea of mixing the songs together to make a continuous dance album, but his production tends to make Madonna's vocals sound weaker than they already are.  Also I find Price's work less soulful and less reflective of disco than some other artists that have put out mock-disco albums such as Luke Vibert (as Kerrier District) and the recently-released Love Songs of the Hanging Gardens by Kelley Polar (which I feel no one will get because, well, Vibert and Polar aren't Madonna).  None of the songs stay in my head except for \\"Hung Up\\" because of its ABBA sample, \\"Sorry\\" and \\"Issac.\\"  As a long time dance music and Madonna fan, I think this is an okay album, but it pales in comparison to other mock-disco albums and Madonna's own Ray of Light.
B000B8QEZG|5.0|It's official: Madonna's fans have received the continuous-mix ear candy they have demanded as a ransom for continued devotion, even if Confessions On A Dance Floor turns out to be anything but superficial. She's sneaky like that. There is a lot going on under that sequin-covered disco cap. I already wrote this on my TypePad blog \\"boy culture,\\" but why bother surfing the Net when you can find out right here: Overall CD Rating: 9/10 <br /> <br /> <br />TRACK BY TRACK <br /> <br />\\"Hung Up\\" <br />The album opens with the ticking of a clock, gutsy for a 47-year-old in a field where her rivals are in their teens and twenties. Though she claims that \\"time goes by so slowly,\\" the exact opposite impression is conveyed, a sense that if you don't seize the moment, it will pass you by. This feeling is helped along by the legendary call to action that is ABBA's bassline from \\"Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight),\\" sampled here to the point of saturation. In the original, it was \\"half past twelve,\\" while in \\"Hung Up\\" it's \\"a quarter to two\\"-maybe time really does go slowly, since in the 26 years from the original's invention to \\"Hung Up\\"'s addictive reinvention, only an hour and 15 minutes have elapsed! The song is an irresistible pop perfect storm with a stop-start quality that manipulates you as easily as the tide toying with driftwood. It's musical crack, and if there is anything to complain about, it's that it's so exactly what the doctor ordered that it's not as surprising as previous lead singles from \\"Like A Virgin\\" to \\"Like A Prayer\\" to \\"Music.\\" At one point in \\"Hung Up,\\" Madonna sings with conviction, \\"I don't know what to do.\\" It's a lie. She knows. 9/10 <br /> <br />\\"Get Together\\" <br />I've never heard a more perfect club song than this euphoric piece, which drips with a sexuality so open it's innocent and begins with a ringing bell that could either be a neat outro providing closure to \\"Hung Up\\"'s 60 Minutes intro or a school bell indicating class is in session/let recess begin. Recalling Stardust's \\"Music Sounds Better With You\\" (itself known to have had a passionate affair with Madonna's seminal hit \\"Holiday\\"), \\"Get Together\\" exudes optimism, boiling down club-hopping to love-seeking. The song is a fantastic example of Madonna's songwriting abilities-here, she writes simply but with feeling: \\"Can we get together?/I really wanna be with you/c'mon check it out with me/I hope you feel the same way, too.\\" This chorus perfectly communicates what we all seek in the darkness of a club-and in life. What else is there? 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"Sorry\\" <br />Rumored to be the set's second single, \\"Sorry\\" is, ironically, another unapologetic vacation for the mind and draft notice for the feet. Opening with Madonna murmuring \\"I'm sorry\\" (or close to it) in several different languages, the song zips along aerobically, as if it were a long-lost Flashdance soundtrack cut. I hear this as a vastly improved take on her admittedly pleasing Erotica tracks \\"Thief of Hearts\\" and \\"Words.\\" Madonna has held out a long time without a classic woman-scorned kiss-off song (\\"You'll See\\" came close). If she was waiting for a worthy cut, her patience pays off with an absolutely grade-A entry in the genre. Pet Shop Boys could have written this for Madonna-it's that good. If this isn't a hit, Billboard is no longer worthy of existing and a flamer fatwa should be called on all radio programmers. 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"Future Lovers\\" <br />A dark-horse candidate for my favorite track on Confessions is this fabulous-in both the gay and non-gay ways-concoction, which finally perfects the psychedelic grandiosity Madonna has occasionally toyed with, notably on \\"Up Down Suite,\\" \\"Bedtime Story,\\" parts of Ray of Light and the enjoyable but somewhat stunted \\"Impressive Instant.\\" While \\"Hung Up\\" arguably fails to wrestle control of its muscular ABBA sample, \\"Future Lovers\\" washes over a soundalike bassline from Giorgio Moroder's \\"I Feel Love,\\" managing to rekindle the excitement generated by Donna Summer's vocal with a completely different, revelatory narrative. Here, Madonna speak-sings, \\"I'm gonna tell you about love\\" (a dozen years after `teaching us how to' you know what on \\"Erotica\\") like a sexy HAL-let's agree to call this song's feminine narrator SAL. When Madonna sings \\"in the evidence of its brilliance\\" with the shrill, almost tinny urgency first heard on \\"Mother and Father,\\" the effect is very different-it's not gut-level intimacy, it's the opposite, a proclamation of the connectedness of the cosmos. Like an astral tour guide (or a drug dealer), Madonna flirtatiously asks, \\"Would you like to try?\\" Who wouldn't? Andy Warhol said, \\"In the future, everybody will be world-famous for 15 minutes.\\" Instead, perhaps in the future everybody will be lovers for 15 minutes. 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"I Love New York\\" <br />The nearly perfect ride through the first four tracks is interrupted by this detour. Early pro reviews raved about this tribute to the city that never sleeps (hey, if Madonna can use clichs, so can I) while early fan reaction has been more mixed, running from ranking it a ways down the list of fave songs on the CD to being embarrassed for Madonna over this clunky American Life illegitimate child. <br />The deftly spare lyrical quality that shines on other songs is supplanted here by a clumsy, juvenile approach that gives birth to you'll-never-live-this-one-down lines like, \\"I don't like cities, but I like New York/other places make me feel like a dork.\\" Dork is a fine enough word, but I think most people who are in love with and in awe of New York would agree that spending a little time here is what makes you feel like a dork, and you feel pretty darn jaded elsewhere. The song is saved from becoming the next \\"I'm So Stupid\\" with a killer chorus, an exhilarating demand to \\"get off my street,\\" Cure-ish guitars and a '60s instrumental wash that evokes images of a beautiful stranger dancing the pony. Is it enough to win youover? Love it or hate it, mad, sad or glad, \\"I Love New York\\" definitely stops traffic-and that's no good when the rest of your CD is a runaway train. I don't despise this song, but I still kinda wish it would F off. Though while we're talking about lyrics, why is no one complaining about \\"my humps, my humps, my humps?\\" 6.5/10 <br /> <br />\\"Let It Will Be\\" <br />This is an odd duck [say it with faux British accent], and not only for the completely unnecessary and (unless I'm missing it) meaningless extra word in the title. Am I insane to be reminded of Iam Siam's \\"She Went Pop?\\" It has an arresting opening that mimics \\"Papa Don't Preach\\" or even\\"Dear Jessie\\" and a vocal with a palpable sense of narrative urgency. \\"Now I can tell you/about success, about fame,\\" Madonna growls, as if relieved to have the good times of the previous tracks behind her as a synthesized cowbell clangs somewhere in the mix. \\"The place that I belong/it won't last long/the lights they will turn down\\" she predicts like a disco Nostradamus. But though she could easily launch into a sermon, she instead preaches to the choir with a prettied up take on a theme stars visit far too often in their work-the dangers of fame, the insubstantial nature of having it all. If this message were broadened to include the kind of success mere mortals are more likely to be inflicted with, maybe. But she's saved by the music and has never sounded more righteous than when she spits, \\"Just watch me burn!\\" Our own little Ciccone of Arc, aflame at the stake of criticism. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />\\"Forbidden Love\\" <br />This charming electro Romeo & Juliet gives me fever-it could be the promise of \\"Future Lovers\\" realized, yet also continues Madonna's more old-fashioned appreciation for a boy and girl in love started in \\"La Isla Bonita.\\" We enter on an odd horn sound that's both playful and desolate, making it easy to envision a video staged on Mars with kisses bestowed from inside spacesuits. It builds to an aural crescendo that lovingly capitulates Moroder's Metropolis work with Queen. Three minutes in, the beat sounds like \\"Vogue,\\" fitting for a song that could reasonably be read as an ode to star-crossed gay lovers or, with more effort, chalked up to the gay-marriage debate-either way, it's hard to resist the urge to chant \\"menergy\\" as you play it. One Madonna song it sounds nothing like is Madonna's own 1994 tune \\"Forbidden Love\\"-I don't count this as self-reflexivity because I'd bet money she simply forgot she was recycling a title. Shimmery and adorable. 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"Jump\\" <br />This kinetic construction is single-worthy for being catchy and universal and yet fresh. Longtime fans will be shocked to hear the raspy spoken-word introduction, which sounds like a throwback to \\"poor is the man whose pleasures depend on the permission of another.\\" This time around, Madonna's saying, \\"There's only so much you can learn in one place/the more that I wait, the more time that I waste,\\" re-emphasizing an Alice In Wonderland \\"I'm late, I'm late, for a very important date\\" theme begun in \\"Hung Up.\\" Further in, the song becomes a semi-remake of \\"Keep It Together\\" with its high praise for family and paraphrasing of Sister Sledge's \\"We Are Family.\\" Engaging songwriting like \\"life's gonna drop you down like the limbs of a tree/it sways and it swings and it bends until it makes you see\\" is brought to life with the most direct vocal on the album. Madonna's pride for her handiwork leaps through. 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"How High\\" <br />A natural progression from a song called \\"Jump,\\" \\"How High\\" is infinitely more pensive. Madonna again returns to questioning fame and fortune, wondering \\"how high?/outer space!/how much fortune can you make?\\" Of achieving her goal of \\"wanting to be talked about,\\" Madonna bitterly admits, \\"I did it/was it all worth it?/and how did I earn it?/nobody's perfect/I guess I deserve it.\\" But while this could be read as Madonna giving herself permission to enjoy her lofty status, it sounds more to me like a very unconvinced \\"I guess I deserve it.\\" Lyrically smart and musically interesting, the song nevertheless fails to live up to its brilliant bookends and isn't half the song that Music's \\"Nobody's Perfect\\" is. 7.5/10 <br /> <br />\\"Isaac\\" <br />\\"Those naughty rabbis\\" took exception when they heard rumors Madonna had named this poorly titled song after Isaac Luria, a 16th Century mystic, and the media decided that the flap somehow meant the song was \\"controversial.\\" This gorgeous masterpiece of a song hasn't got a chance to rise above its silly pre-publicity and be accepted on its own, which is a shame because it's a lush Middle Eastern-flavored gem that's the spawn of \\"Frozen\\" and Sting's \\"Desert Rose\\" with the moaning from \\"Secret\\" thrown in for good measure. Going into the third decade of her career, Madonna is still unafraid to seem pretentious, and that's good because otherwise we might never have had this whirling-dervish slice of musical nirvana. Anyone who hates this is probably hating it out of the mistaken belief that liking it would mean being fooled by Kabbalah. Had this song been named something else and failed to attract the attention of a few self-appointed keepers of Judaism (who leaked it to them so far in advance of whoever leaked it to me?), this could have been a brilliant single. Seriously! 10/10 <br /> <br />\\"Push\\" <br />Madonna has announced that this is a love song to her special Guy. It reminds me of Like a Prayer's Prince-ly \\"Love Song\\" and its challenging \\"Act of Contrition,\\" complete with backward-sounding music and a consistent feeling of struggle. There is a slave-galley rhythm and both the delivery and content of the lyrics communicate effort. Words fall across one another in a jumble like hikers taking a tumble. (Now I'm writing Madonna's next album.) Progress is made, which is good since the song definitely feels like climbing a mountain in 3:45. Quoting The Police's \\"Every Breath You Take\\" and perhapssome Tom Tom Club, the song is certainly not as inaccessible as a mountain aerie. Some hear this as a good single for the American market. I'm still trying to convince myself it's a good album track. 6.5/10 <br /> <br />\\"Like It Or Not\\" <br />It's brand new and yet I feel this song is already underrated. Sure, Madonna has dished out cheek before-mission statements you can dance to like \\"Human Nature\\" have been a large part of her work. But the genius of this song is that while knowing it's coming from Madonna gives it a kick, it is not specific to Madonna's singular experience. It's a wonderful anthem for those who live their lives with no regard for the small minds around them, and for those who wish to God they could. A flash of \\"Die Another Day\\" at the beginning winds down into an almost exact regurgitation of the opening of \\"Frozen\\" (again with the \\"Frozen!\\") before completely about-facing into a giddy declaration of independence set to a clapping percussive beat-if you can close your eyes and picture Madonna snapping her fingers to this and dancing like a Shark or a Jet, you might agree with me when I say I can only believe this song was inspired by her abortive work on the shrugged-off Texas Guinan movie musical Hello, Suckers! The song already role-calls femmes fatales Cleopatra and Mata Hari (Evita is there in spirit), so Tex would fit right in. Regrettably, a lazy lyric like \\"sticks and stones will break my bones\\" detracts from a juicy one like \\"I'll be the garden/you'll be the snake/all of my fruit is yours to take/better the devil that you know/your love for me will grow.\\" Madonna's vocal is reminiscent of \\"He's A Man,\\" especially on that line, and the galloping bassline is a '70s Amii Stewart lark-you better knock, knock, knock on wood, Madonna, that our love for you will grow. But so far, so good. 9/10

B000002I2I|5.0|Most divers album of the Doors. This album sometimes sounds to me like a compilation of leftovers from other albums together with a few new songs. Pretty good leftovers. Waiting For The Sun (not only because it's titel but also because of the way the song is recorded), Blue Sunday and The Spy fit in perfectly with the material of the album Waiting For The Sun. Indian Summer sounds like The End from the first album. You Make Me Real would've done it good on Strange Days. Ship Of Fools and Land Ho! are also songs that remind us of the first three albums. Roadhouse Blues fits in with the live material. Peace Frog, Queen Of The Highway and Maggie McGill are the newer studiosongs the Doors started making since the period of The Soft Parade. <br />We hear a good band, playing good short popsongs. But it's more back to the basics than that creating a whole new sound like they did on The Soft Parade and like they were going to do on LA Woman. <br />That The Spy isn't a leftover may be proven by the version of Queen Of The Highway on the Essential Rarities cd. There you can hear a jazzy version that's very similar to The Spy. But that a lot of songs are difficult to track down to there exact period of making is obvious. Just listen to the early verions from 1965 of Hello, I Love You (from the third album Waiting For The Sun) and Moonlight Drive (from the second album Strange Days) and hear what I mean. Both songs are made before even the first Doors-album came out.  <br />What am I trying to say here? Just that the songs of the first three albums haven't been made in the order of succesion of the albums. I find the chronological order of songs by some other bands to find out. <br />I'm not saying that it's strange that a band has a lot of stuff before the world gets to know them. Maybe it would be a good idea for new bands to work on their repertoire and get some more live-experience before they get an exclusive record deal. It's just that Morrison Hotel has some songs thatmake me think that maybe the Doors dicided to use some old stuff in the difficult period of their existance after the release of the underestimated Soft Parade. If I'm talking nonsense let me know, if I'm right I'd like to know it too. <br /> <br />Something about the songs: <br />Roadhouse Blues needs no introduction. The state Morrison was in gets very clear in the words `I woke up this morning, I got myself a beer'. Great song to use live and another Doors-bluessong. (Every album's got some blues on it, even the Soft Parade.)  <br />Waiting For The Sun is one of the best songs of the Doors. The song starts to `talk' of very normal human behaviour put into poetic words that make the sun a reminder of the garden of Eden.  <br />`At first flash of Eden, we race down to the sea' <br />and <br />`Can you feel it, now the spring has come <br />that it's time to live in the scattered sun' <br />Maybe this is a poetic beachsong? Well, by the way it is sung we already knew beauty can't last for long: <br />`...waiting for you to tell me what went wrong' <br />And in conclusion:  <br />`This is the strangest life I've ever known' <br />Are we waiting for a sun that will never come up?  <br /> <br />Peace Frog starts with the great funky riff of Krieger. But don't get to happie here. Morrison's still alive (no time for jokes yet like on Other Voices). He sings: <br />`blood in the streets, it's up to my ancles'. Not a pretty scene. Very famous are the words `Indians scattered on dawn's highway bleeding...' etc. There in this song too. <br /> <br />Great other songs (among the rest) are: The Spy (the easy listening Doorsjazz with the nice metafore of the spy in the house of love), Queen Of The Highway (wich is played very good, the band is tight, and the lyrics are interesting enough when you think about it:  `No one could save her, save the blind tiger, He was a monster, black dressed in leather, She was a princess, Queen of the highway, hope it can continue a little whilelonger') and Maggie McGill (also played very good, Morrison calls himself a bluesman, and sets the tone for the last album of the 4 Doors). <br />

0140544518|5.0|The True Story of the Three Little Pigs allows readers to think about the classic tale from a different perspective- the wolf's. The papers leave out all of the nice information about the wolf and elaborate on the crimes he committed.  <br /> <br />I love this book because it shows how the media can twist stories around to make them more exciting for the readers. It shows both children and adults how not everything they see or hear about in the news is true. I think this message is especially important in the media-driven society that we live in today. I enjoy this book and recommend it to others.
